Forum Post: 
Post title: SQL returns boolean?
Post description: G'day all, I'm attempting to move a large SQL report-generating query from Ad-Hoc Reports into a cron job, but am butting my head trying to get even the simplest query to work properly. For some reason, any queries I add, as per following, return a "1", aka var_dump of "bool(true)", despite the queries working fine in phpmyadmin? A few things to note; this is added to the end of an existing lib.php triggered by cron, which contains another sql query which works fine - is this an issue?  Other sql uses $DB->get_recordset_select. Here's a simple example; am I doing something stupidly wrong? 
```text
$sqlreport = "SELECT
 c.shortname AS 'Course ID' FROM {course} c";


$reportresults = $DB->execute($sqlreport);


mtrace($reportresults);


var_dump($reportresults);


file_put_contents($reportfile, $reportresults, FILE_APPEND); //create report file
```
 It seems that "execute()" is the correct method to use for arbitrary queries? The above returns the following in phpmyadmin (with the prefix in place) 
```text
Course ID


E247


E248


testSite


SW01


SW02
```
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lee, $DB->execute simply executes an arbitrary query, it doesn't handle returning any data to you. What you're probably after is either: $DB->get_records_sql($sql, $params) or if you're expecting a large recordset, $DB->get_recordset_sql($sql, $params). Both of those functions take extra parameters for limiting and such if you need it. See https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Data_manipulation_API for more detail.
Comment 2: Thanks Adam, I didn't realise that execute couldn't be used to return data. I've been bashing away with get_records_sql for the past few days trying to get somewhere, but I think I may be making things too complicated,  I haven't found a post about this so I'll ask: Does a simple method exist for printing query results to a CSV?  Before I go too far attempting to get the contents from arrays of objects, is there a pre-made function or example of this?  I've found some stuff that uses fopen, a foreach loop with fputcsv, and fclose, which looked promising but I have no idea how to explode the query results in a manner that will create the CSV I need. Any help / pointers would be greatly appreciated.
Comment 3: Take a look at lib/csvlib.class.php, at the csv_export_writer class, although that is just a wrapper for fputcsv. What you are basically wanting is something like this: $fp = fopen('/path/file.csv', 'w'); $records = $DB->get_records_sql('SELECT a,b,c FROM {tablename} ...', $params); You could also use get_recordset_sql instead, if you are just going to loop through the results, and if there may be a lot of results.
Comment 4: Have you tried this add-on: https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=report_customsql Lets you set up queries you can run at any time, and download the results as CSV, or just review them on-screen, with no coding. There is also https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=block_configurable_reports
Comment 5: Thanks Davo, I'll look into that on Monday; so is the "(array)" part verbatim?  That was one of the main roadblocks I came across, in the fputcsv docs it says that part is "fields: Required. Specifies which array to get the data from", and I don't know enough about the structure to have a clue how to specify this. Tim, the query actually currently resides in report_customsql and works as intended, what I'm trying to do is get it to execute on a regular basis and automatically create the csv file on the server ; it's part of an automation process for feeding back into our HR system, which is extremely unwieldly and inflexible.  It can't talk to Moodle, and Moodle can't talk to it (security, etc), so these csv's will be generated in a set location with a set naming convention, an FTP job will pick them up and dump them across to the HR system, which will pick them up and process the results.  Inversely, the HR system creates new account/enrolement csv's, this is FTP'd over to moodledata, and a cron'd process picks them up and processes them into moodle; I have this part working.

```text
General structure
```

Post title: Artificial context object for testing?
Post description: I started this post by describing a particular problem I'm having, but realized that what would be more valuable to me is a more general troubleshooting tool. I frequently find myself asking "what is this function/method returning?", and I can't just create a quick CLI test script because it takes a context object as an argument. I can't be the first person who's had this problem, so I wonder: does there exist a way to just say "create a context object for me as if I was logged in as user X and look at module Y"? If there's no such thing, do people have any other advice for investigating those long chains where X calls Y, which calls Z, which calls... and somewhere along the way something unexpected is happening? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: To get a context object for a course-module id 123: context_module::instance(123) They don't depend on the user looking at it. For general debugging, you could try to install php debugging tools, or the easiest way otherwise is just to call print_object to print relevant information as it goes through. --sam
Comment 2: Thanks for the response! If context is user-independent, then maybe I need to come back to my original question. Basically, I am using an old-style assignment (Moodle 2.2) with a custom type. I'll be upgrading soon and have re-implemented this as a standalone module, but I fear I'll have the same or a similar problem, which is... The assignment mod sends an email to report submission of the assignment to people with the 'grade assignment' permission . In some cases these should go to people assigned at the course level, but in others they should go to mentors, which are assign on a per-user basis. To assign a mentor in this way, I create a 'mentor' role with the 'grade assignment' permission, and then use the 'assign roles relative to this user' link on a student's profile page to grant the mentor role to their mentor's account. Unfortunately, when the user submits an assignment, the course-level graders get an email, but the user-level ones don't. Hopefully context_module::instance() will help me troubleshoot, but perhaps I have a more fundamental misunderstanding here?

Post title: Having Multiple Instances
Post description: Hi All, I want to have moodle 3.3 and 3.4 to run at the same time in my machine. But I do not know how to do this. If anyone know about this please help me. Thanks ! Peshali.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Peshali, A Moodle instance is made of a moodle directory containing all Moodle code, a "moodledata" directory containing all the datas, and a database containing all information. A config.php configuration file is also needed to configure the Moodle instance. So, to have 2 Moodle instances, you need to have all of this in double! And don't mess information in config.php files, each one need to correctly define which directories and database to use! HTH , Séverin PS : of course, these 2 Moodle instances are completly independant!
Comment 2: Hi Severin, Thank you for the reply. But they didn't allow us to start 2 severs. Then what I have to do? Is there any documentation or video? I couldn't find. P.S. - I am new for the moodle and this industry. So please ignore my mistakes. BR, Peshali
Comment 3: You can run multiple moodles from the same server with different code, e.g. yourdomain/mdl33 ands yourdomain/mdl34 If you are limited to a single database you They can point to the same database but with different prefixes, e.g. mdl33_users,mdl_33_courses etc and mdl34_users,mdl_34_courses etc
Comment 4: Also, if you are using the two Moodles at the same time you will have to ensure that Site Admin > Server > Session Handling and the setting "Cookie prefix" is set to two different prefixes. Call one prefix m34_ and the other m33_ or similar to suit.
Comment 5: Hi, Thank you for the replies. I will try and get back to u ;) -Peshali

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to crash MS Edge in one easy step
Post description: Last week, I received a somewhat puzzling report from a user who claimed that he couldn't open files from Moodle in Microsoft Edge.  Upon further investigation, I was able to determine that the trouble was with PDF files displaying embedded in the page: when you open one, Edge stops responding to user input.  You can scroll the page (but not the PDF) - but nothing else; no UI element within Edge will work, and clicking on links does nothing (except occasionally highlight the link).  If you have multiple tabs open and still have it set to warn when closing multiple tabs, attempting to close it via right-click on the taskbar button will pop up that confirmation box - but you can't interact with that, either!  The quickest way to kill Edge when it's in this state seems to be to drag the titlebar down to the bottom of the screen, though you can also use other methods such as ending the task in Task Manager. I was eventually able to track it down to Moodle's embed maximiser script (which resizes the embed to take up as much space as possible on the page).  That script sets the height and width of the embed to 0px briefly, so it can check the size of the page without it present; for some reason, this specific act puts Edge into the strange state where it refuses all input.  I've submitted a patch which instead uses display:none to make the embed take up no space while it calculates - MDL-51190 - which is currently awaiting peer review, but thought I'd post here in case anyone else has been scratching their heads over this issue.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Did you also report this to Microsoft? (Mind you, I have no idea how you would do that.) It seems like a serious bug in Edge.
Comment 2: I've been working on reducing it to a minimal case, so I can provide a demo with my report.  I've pretty much got it sorted, so I'll be reporting it to MS (somehow!) today.
Comment 3: Edge falls over the edge in one easy step.

Post title: Code freeze for 2.9 starts Mon 6 Apr
Post description: Hi, all. This message is to provide notice to developers about the impending code-freeze starting on Monday 6 April. The code freeze is a point after which no new code (only fixes to
existing code) is accepted until beyond the release. This stabilisation
allows for QA testing and means developers are able to respond rapidly
to bugs found. For more information see... http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Process#Events_during_cycle Thanks to all the contributors to Moodle 2.9. We are waiting until all new features land in product and will prepare the release notes page from this list of issues .
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Code freeze officially starts today. Improvements and new features can still be submitted for integration, however they will be held until the end of synchronisation period, which is 3 weeks after release, 1st of June 2015. After this date we will be integrating new features and improvements in 3.0. During this week integration team will go through all the issues that are waiting for integration. However Monday being a public holiday does not help with the queue that is already bigger than usual, so we anticipate that some issues will be carried over the next week. Hopefully we can still start the QA cycle next week as planned. If you are a plugin author, it is probably best to wait until at least
next week before starting to check your plugin for 2.9 compatibility as
this will be a busy week of changes in the codebase. Just a reminder that integration of improvements during the code freeze is still possible but only when approved by the product owner. Issues that are currently waiting for or in peer review will also be considered individually.

Post title: Make $OUTPUT->blocks to add a class to every block in the region
Post description: I'm trying to make that 
```text
$OUTPUT
->
blocks
(
'side-post'
);
```
 add a custom class to every block in the region. I try this way: 
```text
$OUTPUT
->
blocks
(
'side-post'
,
 
'myclass'
);
```
 But it only add the class to the aside tag that have all the div's blocks inside. Any hints? The Docs. of Moodle it's a little confusing.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Not really confusing, I don't think (in this instance anyway) - just that the API doesn't work that way. There is no existing function (as far as I am aware) to add a custom class to every block. To do this you would need to override the renderer that produces blocks - as you have found the $OUTPUT renderer you have used adds the class to the region not to each block.
Comment 2: But i'm searching in Google, and inside of Moodle pages, and theres not a complete documentation for all APIs. For example, de OUTPUT API. Thanks for your answer, i'll check and read about rendering the blocks.
Comment 3: The API is all documented with PHPdoc comments. There is not a compiled HTML version of the docs available online ( http://phpdocs.moodle.org seems to be dead) but you can just read it in the code. E.g. https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/outputrenderers.php#L3702 OK, I see what you mean. The docs for that function are missing the description of some arguments. That is bad. Also, there are overview developer docs online at https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Main_Page
Comment 4: In your theme's overridden 'core_renderer' do something like this: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/outputrenderers.php#L1386 just before this: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/outputrenderers.php#L1552 but you will have to copy / adapt the whole of this: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/outputrenderers.php#L1540 .

Post title: getting user images from external source on moodle2
Post description: Hi all, I had a need to get users images from an external source, meaning I've another directory of users images on another system - and I want to see these picture inside moodle (without copying the images). What I did was a little change on lib/outputrenderers.php at line 1818 (inside the protected function render_user_picture)  in this way: $src="http://myotherserver/".$user->username.".png"; Is this the right way of doing so ? any smarter way ?? tnx, --Yedidia
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The best way to do this is to override the renderer in your theme, rather than modifying the core code - it's a lot easier to maintain. See http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Themes_2.0_overriding_a_renderer for an introduction to overriding renderers.
Comment 2: Mark, thanks a lot - that's the right way that I was looking for! --Yedidia
Comment 3: Sorry about resurrecting an old thread. Any chance you'd be willing to share what you did to put this in place? I've never used the Renderer changes in a theme before. Thanks!
Comment 4: I'd be interested in this as well; the documentation on how to do this is very nebulous for someone who's not very well-versed in PHP, and I haven't found a concrete example of anyone else doing this and documenting it.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Radio button in mod_form sets the checked attribute wrong.
Post description: Hey there, here is my code from mod_form.php: $radioarray=array(); $radioarray[] = $mform->createElement('radio', 'auth', '', get_string('basicauth', MODULE_NAME), 1); $radioarray[] = $mform->createElement('radio', 'auth', '', get_string('oauth', MODULE_NAME), 0); $mform->addGroup($radioarray, 'auth_group', get_string('auth', MODULE_NAME), ' | '); $mform->setDefault('auth', 1); $mform->addHelpButton('auth_group', 'auth', MODULE_NAME); The db field "auth" gets updated correctly when I change the value and the save the form. The problem is, that the active radio button will always be the OAuth one with value 0. Neither does the default value work nor when I explicitly set the checked attribute within the createElement method. As I said, the db field gets updated correctly no matter which value I'm acitvating, but after saving and reopening the form the second element will be active. Could it be, that the default value is somehow cached? Greetings and thanks for any help!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You seem to be missing param 6 of the add_group function ( https://docs.moodle.org/dev/lib/formslib.php_Form_Definition#addGroup ). Without setting this to false, the group modifies the names of the group elements. This may be what is breaking the initialisation of the value.
Comment 2: That was exactly the problem. Thank you very much. greetings

Forum Post: 
Post title: Fatal Error in filterlib.php
Post description: I am getting this error in our Glossary : Fatal error : Maximum execution time of 30 seconds exceeded in /home1/tazonetc/public_html/rosenet/lib/filterlib.php on line 1311 Anybody have any ideas to edit this entry.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This error has been looked at previously however I know the post is old but I think still relevant https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=119598 .  This is a limit which is set on your max_execution_time in the PHP.ini file by increasing this you may resolve the issue if not you may have a loop which is not ending or an error in the code causing the time out but I would test the max_execution_time by setting this high initially to maybe 200 or 300 to see if this resolves the error and if not then look at the code more closely. If it does work try to get the max_execution_time down whilst allowing the code to execute. Hope this helps ;) Scott
Comment 2: Hello Gene, it looks like something is working very slow and there might be a performance issue in moodle that we need to address. Do you have filter_glossary enabled? If yes, try to disable it and see if the site becomes faster. If yes, it means that the slowness is caused by this filter. Which moodle version are you using?
Comment 3: Hello, I had the same problem and I fixed it with your advice (indeed I have a big glossary and used the glossary filter). Thanks a lot. But I have a question : I have this error of max_execution_time of 1s but I have set it at 50000s in php.ini (via my host 's cpanel). So why does it happen ? Is there a way where I can use my big glossary on the entire site without this problem ? Thanks in advance Regards
Comment 4: Changing settings in php.ini require restart of apache service to be seen/used in Moodle. The hint you've given (via hosts cpanel) could indicate your implementation is on a shared system.   On shared systems customers share the resources of a single server .  Hosting providers sell 'packages' which limit ... things like amount of HD space that can be used, etc.   That also includes preventing customers on such server from using up more than their fair share of resources ... thus a cap on PHP settings - how long a script can run, how much memory can be allocated to run a script, etc.    So if your server is on a shared system, you could contact the host helpdesk and inquire about your limits and/or a way to increase the time.   IF on a shared system, the hosting provider may only offer a more expensive package ... or a VPS where you don't have to 'share' those types of resources. The link your Moodle has to Server PHP info should disclose such information for you. Timing out might only be one issue.   Suggest turning on debugging and see what Moodle reports.  There could be other issues related to php settings not in your control. 'spirit of sharing', Ken

Forum Post: 
Post title: get the courseid and groupid from the course that the user is currently acessing
Post description: Hi all, I need to get the courseid and groupid from the course that the user is currently acessing at the moment. The course is a SCORM package. The user enters in the course page and click on a button, it calls a PHP page (same domain ) and show these info. I tried the solution below to get the courseID without success: require("config.php"); $contextid = context_course::instance($courseid); echo " Context id: ".$context->id; thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Rodrigo Based on what you've posted above, it seems you're expecting that $courseid is made available by including config.php?  Unfortunately, this isn't the case.  You will need to pass the courseid to the script though a GET or POST parameter, then access it using require_parameter().
Comment 2: hi mark thanks for the reply. I need the courseId and groupid to use as parameter in the core_group_get_group_members() service and get the usersID for that course/group. this way I can show a list of the users' peers for that particular course and group. I may be wrong but I believe that there is a way to know these 2 parameters calling a php page from inside the course based on these 2 posts: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20576915/how-to-get-the-current-courseid-for-the-current-page-in-moodle https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=101065 on the docs they mention the global variables.... just missing the snippet code... anyone?? https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Developer_FAQ How do I find out the currently-logged-on user? The global object $USER, which contains the numeric $USER->id among other things. How do I find out the current course? The global object $COURSE, which contains the numeric $COURSE->id if anyone knows a easier way to get the users' peers please let me know. my ideia is: - get the userids from core_group_get_group_members() - get the user role from core_user_get_course_user_profiles() to split teacher/students using the role it returns.
Comment 3: Ok, I think those examples you refer to are missing some context. Broadly speaking, there are 2 different types of PHP file in Moodle - libraries, which are not called directly but contain classes and functions, and pages which are called directly.  Libraries will start by declaring the "MOODLE_INTERNAL" constant, while pages will start by including config.php, as in your original example. When you include config.php, you load Moodle's configuration and core libraries, initialise the page's global object in $PAGE, as well as the user's profile and session data via $USER and $SESSION.  However, until you set the page's course by calling $PAGE->set_course() or require_login() and passing in a course id, $COURSE will not be set - there's no way of knowing what it should be. You need to pass to the page either the id of the course, of the id of the course module, or something else within the courses's context that allows you to determine which course you are within. If you are writing a function in a library, you can get current course by doing global $COURSE; at the top of the function - as long as the function will be called within a page that has already done $PAGE->set_course().
Comment 4: Hi Mark, I see your point, to get the course info I need to pass the course id to moodle so it loads the info using the $PAGE->set_course(), makes total sense. The point is that course id along with groupid is the variables i'm looking for. but to the user (student) get to the course content, he logggeid in and accessed the course page. Once he is at the course page I beleive that Moodle has this $COURSE variable set with the std current course details, doesn't? if this is true it should not be difficult to call a simple php page to get the content from this variable.
Comment 5: Yes, when the user is on the course page, code on that page has access to the current course id.  However, if you are then calling another page, that is a separate request so the course id needs to be passed to the new page as part of that request.  The course is not stored as part of the user's session. An example of how you might achieve what you want is to create a block plugin that displays a link on the course page.  Within the block's get_content() method you will be able to do global $COURSE (or even $this->page->course) to get current course ID.  You can then display a link in the block to your new page, passing the course id as a parameter in the URL .
Comment 6: thanks for your clarification and insights mark, I will give a try on that.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Error code: storedfilecannotread
Post description: I did something silly and wanted to share the fix in case someone else did the same thing. When you upload a file (e.g a scorm package) in Moodle through the UI it uses the Moodle file api to store it in moodledata/filedir and point to it in the moodle database table mdl_files. What I did was accidentally delete half of the filedir directory. The person who is responsible for backups realized after I did this that they had no backups. So when you clicked on a scorm activity link, for example, in the course you would see the following error: More information about this error Debug info: [ dataroot ]/filedir/ff/d9/ffd980468bb9a9d42e24991891182efb973eba94 Error code: storedfilecannotread Stack trace: line 454 of /lib/filestorage/stored_file.php: file_exception thrown line 2127 of /lib/filelib.php: call to stored_file->readfile() line 2491 of /lib/filelib.php: call to readfile_accel() line 1005 of /mod/scorm/lib.php: call to send_stored_file() line 4601 of /lib/filelib.php: call to scorm_pluginfile() line 37 of /pluginfile.php: call to file_pluginfile() We had the scorm files though. And so to fix this problem you should access the Moodle database and issue the following command (this sql is just for the scorm file fix): delete from mdl_files where contextid=(SELECT id FROM `mdl_context` WHERE instanceid=(SELECT id FROM `mdl_course_modules` where course=20 and module=18 and instance = (select id from mdl_scorm where name='[name of scorm activity]'))) just subsitute "name of scorm activity" with whatever that activity is named in teh course or database . . . "Module 1" for example. This deletes all the previously associated files in the file system associated with that scorm activity/contextid. Then you just turn on editing in the Moodle UI and re-upload the scorm package for the given activity. Then the link will work again. So this is how i rebuilt the filedir. Of course as I said above this is just for the scorms we had. If you uploaded anything else throught he Moodle UI it would be in the filedir too and therefore be broken.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Git workflow
Post description: Hi, I would like to pick your brains on Moodle git workflows. I have read the documentation, and I'm still unsure about the best path to follow for my use case. I am anticipating code to come from 4 main sources: Moodle codebase, maintained by Moodle HQ on GitHub My own plugins (blocks, modules, themes, etc.) Third-party plugins, used as is (same as above) Third-party plugins, modified to fit my school's needs I will be working with a very small team of developers, none of whom will have access to the server Moodle sits on (including myself), other than running git commands. Should I fork the Moodle codebase (and the third-party plugins that need modifying) and use sub-modules, or go a different route? If I understand it correctly, this would allow me to have a 'moodle' folder with all of the necessary modifications I'd need, in this folder (or at least it would 'look' like it's in the one place). Am I correct in my assumption? Cheers, Fred
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have been struggling with this myself. This is what I do now: I copied the moodle code base, the contributed plugins and my own plugins to a single repo and I deploy from it from the git repo with Capistrano . The disadvantages of this are: My own custom plugins are developed in their own repos, and then I have to go through the extra step of copying them to my "deployable" code base for deployment. I have accidentally made changes to the deployment code on multiple occasions, which gets confusing. I don't like the idea of having a repo with a bunch of code in it that does not really belong. My dissatisfaction caused me to open this topic , which contains some good information. You might also want to check out this topic on adding composer support . Long story short, I am still working on a better solution. To that end, I created an Ansible role which assembles moodle from zip files hosted on moodle.org and github repos. It applies patches too for my code modifications. At the heart of the ansible role is a simple PHP program I wrote called " Tasc " which stands for Tool for Assembling Source Code. It's what does the source code fetching and patching. What all this allows me to do is keep a GitHub repo that contains ONLY a YAML file which describes my Moodle installation and patch files. Here's an example I made: https://github.com/hcpss-banderson/moodle-manifest
Comment 2: Hi Brendan, Thank you for your insights and all of the links you have shared with me. It has given me much food for thoughts. I will have to check with the IT team at the school, as I have not been given rights to run some of the services you mention in your post. Cheers, Fred
Comment 3: Both Capistrano and Ansible run on the deployment box not the server being deployed to. Capistrano will run git and move files around. That's it. Ansible will do whatever you tell it to do. So if you only ask it to run git, then that's what it will do. They are both just ways to automate a process that you design. What you are asking about is how the process should be designed. So I would work that out first. Either can be adapted to whatever git strategy you choose. What I am trying to sell you on is a world where your git repository contains nothing but the bare minimum of what is needed to build your site. Personally, every time I get something from github or even moodle.org and put it in my own repo, I shed a tear.
Comment 4: Thank you, Brendan for the clarification. I will definitely keep looking at the workflow you have outlined. I'd wrongly assumed that the scripts needed installing on the production server. Cheers, Fred
Comment 5: Hi Fred, Sometimes it seems as though there are as many different ways to manage Moodle + plugins + customisations as there are Moodle instances... Personally, I use essentially the approach you've suggested: I have a fork of the main Moodle repo, which contains branches based on the MOODLE_XX_STABLE branches which I'm working with.  My branches contain customisations to core, along with plugins included as submodules.  In order to upgrade to a new version of Moodle, I rebase my branch onto the appropriate upstream MOODLE_XX_STABLE branch. The main thing with using submodules is that you need to remember that a `git pull` on the main repo won't update the submodules themselves - something along the lines of `git submodule update --init` covers most bases (new and/or updated submodules), though if submodule repo URLs change, you may also need to run a `git submodule sync` before the submodule update.
Comment 6: Hello, from my experience, "git submodules" is not the best tool for the job, as also mentioned by Paul Nicholls. You may be interested in Composer as also mentioned by Brendan Anderson. Also, for more "robust" or "complete" (or sometimes "overkill") solutions out there, there are some people using Docker ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=278759 ) and this new "ansible" approach seems to be a nice one (other tools like that are Chef  ( https://www.chef.io ) and the old Puppet ( https://puppetlabs.com/ ) ) if you really have a lot of patches in core and so. Kind regards, Daniel
Comment 7: Hi Daniel, Thank you for the links. I will be looking at Chef in more detail. Cheers, Fred
Comment 8: Hi Paul, Thank you for sharing your workflow. I totally agree with your first statement, everyone has a system that seems to work for them, but would not be suitable to others for x or y reason. Cheers, Fred
Comment 9: My own approach is much like the one Paul Nichols describes. I have a fork of a Moodle STABLE to which I then apply patches and submodules. Rather than rebasing, though, I have lately started just merging in core updates, and that seems to be going well. It gets tricky when maintaining a fork of a third-party module, though I have done it in a couple cases. The trickiness comes when you have submodules pointing to multiple repos on dev but not in production. I also typically have a couple things in dev that are not part of production at all and I use the file at .git/info/exclude to avoid tracking them. I am a fan of submodules, despite the complications, because I like tracking all the modules in my main Moodle fork history. Using submodules does not necessarily prevent you from also using some additional deployment tool which could then run the submodule update command for you. I have not so far used any, however.
Comment 10: Hi Kevin, Thank you very much  for sharing your workflow here. I am still weighing up the options, and it's great to hear that you've had success using sub-modules. Cheers, Fred
Comment 11: Our preferred method for managing client codebases uses submodules, Gerrit, and client specific branches. The steps we go through: Checkout MOODLE_29_STABLE Fork a client branch, eg. git checkout -b clientname-version-sitetype. Push to Gerrit. Add plugins using submodules. Submodules repos are also on Gerrit. If a plugin requires customisation, fork a new branch from the submodule, and push it to the Gerrit repo. To manage code changes, we use Gerrit for code reviews, and controlling what patches are merged. Gerrit also handles submodules nicely - if a patch is merged in a submodule branch, and a project tracks that submodule branch, the parent project will automatically be updated. This removes the overhead of managing submodule changes in the parent project. It probably wouldn't be too hard to script this if you weren't using Gerrit. Merging upstream releases of core or plugins is pretty simple. Just merge the latest parent branch, push, and test. The biggest advantage of using submodules like this is keeping all the plugin code separate. Tracking upstream plugin changes if plugins are part of the main repo can be a serious pain. Deployments are a separate issue, and there are many ways to do it. I've used capistrano, debian packages, git checkouts, CI tools... Currently one project I manage uses GoCD and Jenkins. This can be overkill for some projects though. Another uses custom bash scripts with git-archive-all to create a tarball of the full codebase, which is then extracted on the servers. That works well enough.
Comment 12: Hi Chris, Thank you for sharing your workflow, I didn't know of Gerrit. It looks like a very promising tool, thank you! I am starting to get a much clearer picture of what would look like a good solution for our needs. Cheers, Fred
Comment 13: I've found this thread very interesting and am grateful for all of the suggestions shared. I will be looking into Capistrano , Ansible , Chef , Composer , Docker , Gerrit, GoCD , Puppet and Tasc . It's been a few years since I last looked into these types of tools so there may now be something to suit my needs. My situation is a little more complicated than yours because I need to support multiple version of Moodle and multiple versions of plugins in several cases. One of the things you keep in mind is that the GitHub repositories for 3rd party plugins rarely contain the same code as the released code on moodle.org/plugins. In some cases the code is behind while in other cases it is ahead (i.e. new version in development/testing). Be aware and be careful of this as you can end up breaking plugins and your Moodle site. With very few exceptions, the only git repo that I typically clone is Moodle itself. What I've done is to setup a directory tree structure and have a bash script that assembles/updates a Moodle site with plugins, as needed. Here is an example of my directory structure which matches where plugins would be placed if in the Moodle directory tree (minus the plugins directory). Moodle moodle/ Unlike the rest of the directories below, this is a clone of my Moodle fork repository on GitHub which includes all versions of Moodle so it can easily be switched from one version to another when creating a new site. I can also simply merge recent updates into the code. If I need to create a pull request, I will create separate branche (with tracking enabled!) and push it to my GitHub fork. If the core code gets updated before my modifications are merged into the core code, I can rebase my patch branches to merge changes. If you never plan on submitting fixes for Moodle core code, you can skip having a fork on GitHub to make things a little simpler. When I create a new Moodle site, I simply copy the files to a new location on my webserver and git checkout the desired MOODLE_XX_STABLE branch. If you do a lot of core patches, you may also want to have your own branch which integrates all of your fixes so that you don't have to wait for fixes to be integrated into the core code. Plugins I put all of my 3rd party plugins under a folder called plugins. They are organized in the same structure as if they were in the directory tree of Moodle making it easy to keep track of the types and locations of plugins. For example: plugins/auth/ plugins/availability/conditions plugins/blocks/ plugins/course/format plugins/enrol/ plugins/filter/ plugins/lib/editor/atto/plugins/ plugins/lib/editor/tinymce/plugins/ plugins/local/ plugins/mod/ plugins/report/ plugins/theme/ Inside each of the above directories, I have a directory for each plugin of each version of Moodle. Unlike with Moodle, this is necessary because there is no standard organization of branches in plugins. The main branch in some plugins might be "master" while others, like Configurable Reports, might be CR_23_STABLE. For example: plugins/mod/attendance24 plugins/mod/attendance25 plugins/mod/attendance26 plugins/mod/attendance27 plugins/mod/attendance28 plugins/mod/attendance29 In this case, there is a release for each version of Moodle the Attendance activity module. However, in cases where a version of the plugin is the same across several versions of Moodle, subsequent directories would actually be symlinks so that I only need to make changes in one place when making modifications: plugins/mod/groupchoice22 plugins/mod/groupchoice23 (symlink to groupchoice22) plugins/mod/groupchoice24 (symlink to groupchoice22) plugins/mod/groupchoice25 (symlink to groupchoice22) plugins/mod/groupchoice26 (symlink to groupchoice22) plugins/mod/groupchoice27 plugins/mod/groupchoice27 (symlink to groupchoice27) plugins/mod/groupchoice28 (symlink to groupchoice27) plugins/mod/groupchoice29 (symlink to groupchoice27) My script removes the version number at the end of the plugin's directory name. Custom/Customized Plugins (optional) Although not required, I also maintain a separate "cplugins" directory tree at the same level as "plugins" where I put plugins that I've ether developed myself or 3rd party plugins that I've customized. It makes my build script a little more complicated but makes it easier for me to easily see what I need to maintain. Managing plugin source code As I previously mentioned, git repos are not consistently reflective of the current stable release on Moodle.org/plugins. What you can do is to setup each of these plugin directories as it's own local repo. Then, each time you download a new version of the plugin, replace the existing code (but not the .git directory) with the new version you downloaded and create a new commit for it. This will enable you to move forward and backwards in versions of the code as needed. I've tried using git subtrees (not submodules) and run into directory structure issues that I was unable to resolve in an automated way. The advantage of having your plugins separate from your Moodle code is that you can then have a system whereby you can pick and choose which plugins to include into the instance of a particular Moodle site. If designed right, this same system can double as a way to add new plugins into existing instances of Moodle and update existing plugins in a given site. Even if you maintain only one Moodle site, the ability to create multiple sites can be a real benefit. For example you might want to test a new plugin, a new version of a plugin or a new version of Moodle without impacting your production site. Save even more time/effort/money the Open Source way Whenever you customize a 3rd party plugin, depending on the nature of the customization, I encourage you to contribute your modifications back to the original author through a pull request. Some managers will see this as giving away the results of your time and effort but, since you feel are doing the work anyway, little additional effort is required to share the changes back to the author. Explain to him/her the true long term benefit of participating in Open Source. Think about it. Each time you download a plugin, you are receiving hundreds or even thousands of hours of time and effort that one or more people put into this for free. Why return the favour by sharing your customizations with the author? If the author also thinks this would be a great addition, he/she will integrate the changes into the core plugins code. The best part is that, once integrated into the plugin, your modifications will be perpetually maintained and supported by the author of the plugin and possibly even enhanced over time. The same can be said for Moodle core. This means that, when comes the time for you to upgrade to a newer release of Moodle, the modifications will already be upgraded for you and you won't have to spend any time, money or effort re-applying your changes. It's a win-win situation. You get free maintenance enhancements for the life of the plugin and the Moodle world benefits from your genius and may even raise your awareness of issues you didn't think of before it impacts your users. In general, I've found many Moodle plugin developers to be very responsive and appreciative and open to most contributions. I've submitted issues, fixes and enhancements to 3rd party plugin developers and seen them integrate the changes into their core code not within years, months or weeks, but often literally days or even hours and occasionally even within minutes of sharing changes with them depending on the complexity of the change. You will only see this in the open source community. Microsoft, Apple and other large companies? They might require you to pay for a subscription or at the very least charge your credit card just so that you can report an issue to them. In my experience, unless you are a MAJOR client, the response in the end is often something like "This issue may be addressed in a future release". Will it? Think of it from a business perspective. Why fix an issue if you are making money from it being broken? They have shareholders to keep happy. Imagine if that was the way things went in the Open Source community. Progress would be slowed down to a snails pace. Even if the author of a Moodle plugin has abandoned their project or is too busy to respond, you've got the support of the whole Moodle community to help you out. If you don't like the direction in which a plugin is going, you can fork it yourself and customize it to your hearts content however you loose the benefits and handing off future maintenance and upgrades of your plugin. I've digressed a little here but the point is that sharing back to the community should also be part of your git workflow. Additional development tools On a side note, you might also find the Moodle MDK command line tool to be useful in addition to Moosh previously mentioned in this thread. As part of your QA testing, the Moodle Code Checker plugin can help you get 98% of the way to meeting Moodle coding style guidelines . Hope you find something useful in all of this. Best regards, Michael Milette
Comment 14: Hi Michael, Thank you very much for sharing your workflow, very interesting indeed. I too have learnt a lot through this thread. I wholeheartedly agree with the pull requests to developers and Moodle HQ. This is not something I was at liberty to do in the past, and I have already started selling the idea to my new management (I have moved schools). Hopefully I will get my point across. I will have a lot of thinking to do over the next few working days, and the information in this thread has been invaluable. It won't prevent us from pushing some repos to the cloud, should that be allowed by management. Cheers, Fred

So let me suggest - if you realize some plugin is updated without meaningful and useful release notes, go ahead and report it as a bug in their issues tracker.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to create a new Role to enroll students?
Post description: Hi there, I am trying to set up a Moodle site that caters to small institutes in my area. Here is a Problem I am facing and hoping to find a solution. I need to create a new Role say "Course Enroler" that can do just the following things and nothing else. The reason being, I don't want the administrative staff to tamper with any of the course activities . Enrol/Unenrol Students to/from a particular course Edit details of all those Students enrolled in a particular course. I did go through the Documentation page for creating new roles but failed to understand  what all boxes I need to tick for creating a Role that suits my requirements after going to Administration > Site administration > Users > Permissions > Define roles and Clicking the "Add a new role" button. Would really appreciate it if someone can help me with this. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Any help would be appreciated!
Comment 2: Hi Sriharsha, erm.... actually, you have asked this question in the wrong forum, it would be better placed in the General Forum. Having said that, let's see of we can work it  out anyway - it would have been easier if you had given your Moodle version number, but this is for v2.7. The essentials are the same, but some things will be different. You do not need anything fancy, for the Role is already in your Moodle, all you have to do is to coax it out. Go to Site Admin > Users > Permissions > Define Roles and that will get you started. If you look at the list of Roles you will see one called "Non-Editing Teacher". This Role has access to a course, can do things in it like view grades and so on, but cannot edit course materials, so that is a long way towards what you are looking for. Click on the Add a New Role button at the bottom of the Roles list and select in the "Use role or archetype" drop down list, non-editing teacher then click on Continue button. Give the new Role a name, then a formal name. You need to be able to assign this Role either at a site wide level or a Category level, so click on the checkbox everywhere you want it to be assigned, but be careful, make sure the Role works before assigning it. You want the Role to enrol students, so in "Allow Role Assignments" select "Student" and deselect Student and Guest from the "Allow Role Switches" list. This should already be turned off, but in your find dialogue, enter Switch and search for the Capability. It is about the third entry located starting from the top of the page. If the "Allow" checkbox is ticked, then turn it off. What I am suggesting here is to change these if they have ticks in the Allow box, and I suggest NO then turn it off, if no tick, then don't worry about it. The reverse is true, if the recommend is YES then turn it on. Where there is a ??? then suit yourself. I have taken a lot of permissions out, so leave them at the default setting unless otherwise indicated. You can always change them to suit your need or if it is not working then add or subtract capabilities to suit. Create a test user and assign the Role AFTER you have hit the "Create this Role" button. Test it thoroughly before using it. Good luck.... View suspended users    YES moodle/course:viewsuspendedusers Send messages to any user    ??? moodle/site:sendmessage View participants     YES - essential moodle/site:viewparticipants Create users moodle/user:create     - This allows the Role to access the ENTIRE User list, and add a new to the Moodle User think about this one. Delete users moodle/user:delete   -The allows this Role to delete Users from the ENTIRE User list, think about this one too. Update user profiles   YES, a requirement of your Role moodle/user:update User upload Yes or No? I suggest NO, they can add new Users, if you granted that above, but one at a time, usually the way with a late enrolment. Upload user pictures tool/uploaduser:uploaduserpictures Edit user profile   - YES, a requirement of your Role. moodle/user:editprofile View user full information - NO, not necessary moodle/user:viewalldetails Add and remove cohort members   YES, if you are using Cohorts moodle/cohort:assign Create, delete and move cohorts     No, irrespective moodle/cohort:manage Create courses      DEFINITELY NOT moodle/course:create Cohort sync              NO Configure cohort instances enrol/cohort:config Unenrol suspended users   YES enrol/cohort:unenrol External database Unenrol suspended users   ??? enrol/database:unenrol Flat file (CSV) Manage user enrolments manually     NO enrol/flatfile:manage Unenrol users from the course manually NO enrol/flatfile:unenrol Guest access Configure guest access instances   NO enrol/guest:config LDAP enrolments         NO Manage LDAP enrol instances enrol/ldap:manage Manual enrolments  ??? Intially NO but circumstances may change that. Configure manual enrol instances enrol/manual:config Enrol users                YES requirement of the Role enrol/manual:enrol Manage user enrolments       YES, requirement of the Role enrol/manual:manage Unenrol users from the course  YES, requirement of the Role enrol/manual:unenrol Unenrol self from the course    Leave as is, you do not assign the Role in the course anyway. enrol/manual:unenrolself Unenrol suspended users     YES, for metacourses if you use them enrol/meta:unenrol PayPal Configure PayPal enrol instances   NO, this is done another way so leave as is, enrol/paypal:config Manage enrolled users enrol/paypal:manage Unenrol users from course enrol/paypal:unenrol Unenrol self from the course enrol/paypal:unenrolself Self enrolment    Leave as is, self is taken care of elsewhere. Configure self enrol instances enrol/self:config Manage enrolled users    ??? enrol/self:manage Unenrol users from course ??? enrol/self:unenrol Unenrol self from the course ??? enrol/self:unenrolself Course View site-wide cohorts ??? is this necessary? moodle/cohort:view Send a message to many people  ??? May or may not be useful, moodle/course:bulkmessaging View hidden user fields  YES, for editing moodle/course:viewhiddenuserfields View participants moodle/course:viewparticipants Restore user data   NO moodle/restore:userinfo Assign roles to users    YES, assing the Student Role to sudents enrolling in a course moodle/role:assign Always see full names of users    YES, requirement of the Role moodle/site:viewfullnames See full user identity in lists    NO, not necessary. moodle/site:viewuseridentity Login as other users   NO moodle/user:loginas View user profiles   YES moodle/user:viewdetails View hidden details of users  YES moodle/user:viewhiddendetails Reveal student identities   NO mod/assign:revealidentities Review grades  NO mod/assign:reviewgrades Submit assignment  NO mod/assign:submit View assignment   NO mod/assign:view View grades   NO mod/assign:viewgrades Submit assignment  NO mod/assignment:submit View assignment    NO mod/assignment:view Read book  NO View hidden book chapters  NO mod/book:viewhiddenchapters Activity: Chat    NO to all Activity: Choice  NO to all Activity: Database NO to all Activity: Feedback  NO to all Activity: Folder   NO to all Activity: Forum  NO to all Activity: Glossary NO to all Activity: Advanced Forum NO to all Activity: IMS content package  NO to all Activity: Lesson NO to all Activity: LTI NO to all Activity: Page NO to all Activity: Questionnaire  NO to all Activity: Quiz   NOI to all Activity: File View resource   YES mod/resource:view Activity: SCORM package  NO to all Activity: Survey  NO to all Activity: URL NO to all Activity: Wiki NO to all Activity: Workshop  NO to all Activities NO general capabilities for Activities are required I suggest Manual grading report NO to all grading Quiz statistics report  NO Repository  NO to all View list of online users block/online_users:viewlist

Forum Post: 
Post title: Simple question about Moodle Events
Post description: After reading the documentation on Moodle Events ( https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Event_2 ) I have a simple question about them which I'm guessing somebody could quickly confirm that my understand is correct (before I go ahead and test it). I have an existing plugin which through an overnight cron job, takes all the data in mdl_user_info_data and normalises it into a new table, where every additional profile field is a column in the table (called userdata) I'm now looking to improve this plugin to make the updates to my plugin table instant, rather than wait for the overnight cron job. From my understanding of the Events this should be possible by: adding a file db/events.php to my plugin listen for core/event/user_updated within the $observers array and call my custom function (defined within the callback param). My custom function would update my userdata table when a user profile is updated. I could also 'observe' other events such as user_created and user_deleted to do other things on my custom table. Is my understanding correct and do other authentication methods trigger the same events, for example if a user is created via LDAP authentication would it trigger the same user_created event? Thanks in advance
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes, that sounds about right. I've generally found that core Moodle plugins "do the right thing" with events (e.g. auth plugins will call user_create_user() when creating a user, triggering an event), but if you need 100% accuracy the only way to be sure is to check the code! If you're using Moodle 2.7 or higher, it might also be worth considering creating ad-hoc tasks rather than updating your database directly in the event handler. It's pretty easy to introduce performance problems with event handlers that are doing anything but the simplest things, so it's often preferable just to create an ad-hoc task that will be run next time the cron job runs. It's not instant, but it sounds like that might not matter for your use case.
Comment 2: Great - thanks for your help.

Post title: [how_to] Forms - set date_selector with 'optional' => true to enabled by default?
Post description: In a date_selector with the option  'optional' set to true to show the »Enabled« checkbox the checkbox should be activate by default. Moodle sets the checkbox to off and I don't find a way to change the default behavior. I tried several variants of the » disabledIf« statement but without success - I guess because the »Enabled« checkbox is generated internally. 
```text
$mform->disabledIf('mycontrol', 'somecheckbox', 'checked');
```
 Is there a possibility to activate »Enabled« by default? Thanks a lot for any help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you need it enabled you need to set default value. 
```text
class myform extends moodleform {


    protected function definition() {


        $mform = $this->_form;


        $opts = array(


            'startyear' => 1970,


            'stopyear'  => 2020,


            'timezone'  => 99,


            'optional'  => true,


        );




        $mform->addElement('date_selector', 'assesstimefinish', 'aaaaaa', $opts);


        $mform->setDefault('assesstimefinish', time() + 3600 * 24);
```
Comment 2: Thanks a lot Darko, so easy but not obvious at all.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Creating a new Scorm instance to a course without using mform
Post description: Hi, I'm working in to automate the creation of Scorm instance inside moodle (2.5) via webservices from an external application. The webservice receives the course id and the Scorm zip url to download , inside my local plugin I download the package, insert it in the moodle filesystem, etc., and I build all the moduleinfo object with all the data I need. But my problem is when I want to excecute the scorm_add_instance from the scorm lib it ask me for the $mform object, but I don't have it, because I'm not using any moodle form, and If I don't pass the $mform object it does not process my draft package. Is it possible to bypass or build a custom $mform object? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: From a quick look at the code, it appears that, back in Moodle 2.5, the $mform object was used to copy the file into the correct location (this doesn't appear to be necessary in Moodle 2.7). You may have some success with using the scorm_dndupload_handle function instead, or, alternatively, you could use the Moodle Files API to add the SCORM file to the correct location ( context = module context id; component = mod_scorm; filearea = package; itemid = 0) and then just call scorm_add_instance, with $mform set to null.

Post title: Can't get a plugin to show up in navigation
Post description: I'm currently in the process of building a plugin, but for some reason it's impossible for me to get the plugin to show up in the navigation. In the file mod/signature/lib.php I've got the following code: 
```text
function signature_extend_navigation($navigation, $course, $module, $cm) {


    global $CFG;




    $target = $CFG->
wwwroot
.'/mod/signature/index.php';


    $navigation->add('Digitaal ondertekenen', $target, navigation_node::TYPE_RESOURCE, null , null, new pix_icon('i/group' , ''));


}
```
 But this doesn't seem to be working. According to the documentation and an example module I've downloaded, this should be the way to go, so what's wrong here? Why won't this make my plugin show up?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That should be fine. Your entry should show up in the specific instance navigation when you click on an instance of that module in a course. Are you looking in the correct navigation menu? Also, make sure you have purged your caches. mike
Comment 2: I wasn't trying to display it only in courses. It has to be shown on every page for every logged in user.
Comment 3: That function will add it to the Administration menu under the entry "Signature administration". You will only see that when you are accessing the signature activity. If you see your entry there, then the function is working correctly. To display to every user on every page, you may want to inject into the user preferences or profile feature. Or you could use a theme that allows you to add menu entries. Or you could create a block that you then add to all pages of the site. mike

Forum Post: 
Post title: Plugin status ...
Post description: Hi everybody, Is there a way to know if a specific plugin is installed ? enabled ? I am developing a plugin for provisional enrolment to my site. I need to known in my theme plugin if the provisional enrolment plugin is installed and enabled so I will add a link (or not) to it in my header. Thanks in advance. Best regards, Tistou
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you are using Moodle 2.7 or higher it's easy ! 
```text
Site administration > Plugins > Plugins overview
```
 You can then see something like: "Installed: 354    Disabled: 67     Additional: 1" and also a link: "Show additional plugins only" (I'm not sure if this was available in 2.6 too?)
Comment 2: Hi M. Mealor, First of all, thanks for your answer. I misspoke, I would like to have this information in my PHP code, not by using the user interface. Best regards, Tistou
Comment 3: There isn't a generic 'is this plugin installed and enabled' function in Moodle (maybe there should be, but 'enabled' is determined in different ways for different plugins). However, in the case of enrolment plugins you're in luck. enrol_is_enabled('name of enrol plugin'); // Returns true if the plugin is enabled enrol_get_plugin('name of enrol plugin'); // Returns the plugin, or null if it is not installed. See lib/enrollib.php, enrol_try_internal_enrol() for an example of this in use.
Comment 4: Hi M. Smith, Thanks for your answer, that was exactly what I was searching for. Best regards, Tistou

Post title: Blocks CSS - Any standard classes?
Post description: I'm working on styling a new block. I was hoping to have my button styles follow those of whatever theme is being used, but I can't find if here are any standard element classes in available. I came across a few pages on moodle.org related to this, but it looks like the work has been abandoned, but the pages left up. https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Element_HTML_and_CSS_guidelines (Tracker issue says project is dead) https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Output_element_planning (Tracker issue closed and points to this page, but seems to be part of the above project) https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Render_library_specification (Already closed. Part of same project) Is there anything going on in this area? Either way, what are best practices here? My first thought was to use bootstrap styles (class="btn btn-primary"), but I realize not all themes use bootstrap. Any advise?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well, you could still use the bootstrap classes and add the relevant bootstrap css to your block /styles style sheet if you think there will be significant use with non-bootstrap themes. But bootstrap styling is pretty much the accepted way to do things in moodle, the other non-bootstrap themes in the plugins database are essentially legacy ones, although some may still be in use. The slightly bigger issue is if you use boostrap classes which have changed between BS versions (panels v cards for example)

Post title: Plugins with dependencies on php extensions
Post description: We have a plugin that just assumes the existence of mcrypt. (It is not one of our own developments). I have been trying to find out how this ought to be handled in a Moodle way? I know you can check for the existence of extensions or functions, but is there a way of preventing plugin installation in the same way that $plugins->dependencies does for Moodle modules, if a particular php extension is a dependency?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The closest you could get, as far as I am aware, would be to create a file db/install.php, with a function xmldb_MYPLUGINFULLNAME_install() and in that function you could output an error and halt the installation process. The downside is that install.php only runs after the database tables for your plugin have been added, so there may be someone out there who knows a better solution.
Comment 2: There is now support for 
```text
environment.
xml
```
 files in plugins that address this. I am afraid it has not been documented properly yet (any help welcome!) but you can find some info in MDL-39840 and here .
Comment 3: Thank you so much Davo and David.

Post title: Unit testing Messaging, database environment not resetting between tests.
Post description: I'm working on writing a bunch of unit tests for an existing custom body of work (which I've talked extensively about distributing before, to a fairly cold response). So far, the tests have been going OK - but I've written some tests to make sure event observers were being called correctly, and this is where things are falling over. When this specific action I'm testing occurs, it generates a notification to the staff and student using the messaging system to state that the action occurred. Two scenarios can occur; One for an instance of an Assign module and one for an instance of a Quiz module. My tests are structured that they extend a base test class which contains setup/teardown code. In setUp() the course used for the test is setup, staff and students are added correctly (they have their own assertions which are all passing as expected), Groups and Groupings are added (again, checked with assertions). In tearDown() the variables are unset to hopefully prevent these staying around. In the test themselves, they are essentially duplicated. Test 1 creates an Assignment module instance, assigns the grouping to the module instance and sets other basic information such as the due date etc (all checked with assertions). We then apply the extension (this is our custom code, not the core extensions which are not very advanced) to a group inside the grouping, this all works OK (all assertions pass), the event is called (assertions for this pass too) and the observer picks up and calls the required code to generate the message. In this test, this passes all assertions correctly. Test 2 does the same process as Test 1, with the required changes to create a Quiz module instance rather than an Assignment module. Everything passes all assertions until the Message is generated - for, get this, the Assignment module instance created in the previous test! The module instance created in Test 1 and Test 2 both end up with the same Course Module ID! It's like the whole environment isn't being reset between tests. In each test that is testing the observer and messaging, I've tried calling $this->preventResetByRollback(); as I've seen in other tests - but no change. I've tried with and without $this->preventResetByRollback() with no change. I can switch the order of these tests and whichever is run last fails as it's using the module created by the previous test. I can comment out either of the tests and on their own they both run successfully. I can comment out all other tests (three others, no messaging stuff), same result. I am rebuilding the course cache at the top of each test, again after the module instance is created, and then again at the end of the test itself. I have confirmed Setup/Teardown are being executed before and after each test: 
```text
Moodle 2.9.2+ (Build: 20150924), pg
sql


PHPUnit 3.7.38 by Sebastian Bergmann.



Configuration read from C:\moodle\my_phpunit.
xml


.Setup called Setup complete. Tear down calledTeardown complete


..................Setup called Setup complete. Running test_quiz_global_extension_observer
```

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I've now tried these tests in my local Linux dev environment with no change to the result..
Comment 2: " The module instance created in Test 1 and Test 2 both end up with the same Course Module ID! " " It's like the whole environment isn't being reset between tests. " In fact, the conclusion you should reach is the opposite! The whole environment is being reset between tests. Therefore, in each test, the first activity created is getting a particular id. The method preventResetByRollback() is not preventReset(). Rollback will always happen. The only question is how it is done. Are you doing any caching in the code you are testing? (E.g. a static variable with stores things by cmid?) If so, don't do that. Use Moodle's caching system MUC, which does get reset properly between tests.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Potentially breaking YUI changes in today's master, test your plugins now!
Post description: Hi All, In the slow march towards weaning ourselves off YUI, i've just removed the mcore YUI rollup from being included on every single Moodle page ( MDL-57690 ). This was including a few Moodle YUI modules unconditionally all the time (dock loader, popup help, and widget/dialogue modules) and so if you are using of any of these modules without explicitly declaring the dependency it may not have been detected before. Now that those modules are not being included unconditionally your code may break. It would be a good time to test your plugins early against master this week using boost. Or grep your code for instances of `M.core.dialogue` (which was the main thing we detected undeclared dependencies in core code).

Forum Post: Post title: Seeking a "show/save aribtrary input data" plugin Post description: Greetings-- I am a software developer who is brand new to Moodle, and fairly new to PHP (though I've done extensive server -side scripting with other technologies, mostly ASP/VBscript/ SQL Server).  As such, I'm still wading through the Moodle docs , so please excuse me (and correct me) if I misuse the terminology; and please advise me if posts like this belong in a different forum. We have been charged with finding, or building, a plugin that provides functionality like this: Content creator generates an activity that looks mostly like an HTML page, except it includes specially coded spaces (text inputs) in which student can enter data, which is saved.  (At this point, it's reminiscent of an "Embedded Answer (Cloze)" quiz question; but it's not quite the same thing.) Content creator may create several such activities .  The "identifier" for a text item in one activity may match an identifier for a text item in a different activity.  In such a case, any text the user may have previously entered, matching that "identifier", in this or ANY OTHER similar activity, will populate the field. Content creator may specify an instance of a field to be "read-only", in which case student's previously-entered value will just show up (in that activity) as inline text, not as a text entry box. Student may edit the values in the text fields at any time (except in activities where they're marked as read-only). Content creator will define the unique names for the field identifiers (subject to some syntax restrictions TBD). If possible, we would like the student's entered values to be preserved across courses, so that an activity of this type in course "B" may be populated with the values that the student entered while in course "A".  In this sense, the entered values are somewhat like pieces of the student's "profile". Does anyone know of an existing plugin that works this way? Thanks! - Rick Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: I don't know of any activity like this. However, you may want to consider creating a Moodle filter instead of an activity. A filter is basically a way to do search/replace on any input before it is output, for example in the contents of a page resource, but it will work anywhere. For example there are several filters running here. If I type [ [Debugging] ] without the spaces, that will get replaced with a link ```text Debugging ``` (but without the extra spaces, which I have added to stop another filter, one which looks for anything like a URL and turns it into a clickable link. If I just type https://docs.moodle.org/en/Debugging then that will become a link without me doing anything. So, if you want, you could make a filter that looks something like {{name=inputid|width=30}} or {{name=inputid|width=20|readonly}} in the text, and replaces it with a text box. You would probably then also need some JavaScript / Ajax code to handle putting in the value, and saving it when it changes. See https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Filters for docs. This approach is probably simpler than building an activity, but is not without its issues. E.g. How do you stop students typing that sort of thing into a forum? (The answer might be https://docs.moodle.org/28/en/Managing_filters - only enable the filter in the places you need it.) Comment 2: Tim -- Thanks!  That looks very promising.  I will read up on Filters and give it a try. Label:

Post title: Is context_module::instance deprecated?
Post description: Hello. I am the maintainer of activity module called MooTyper. With Moodle 2.6.4 and MooTyper 2.4 I'm getting some strange issue with context_module::instance call. In file view.php on line 221 I have this: 
```text
if (has_capability('mod/mootyper:setup', context_module::instance($course->id)))
```
 The code crashes and prints the following development message: Debug info: SELECT id,course FROM {course_modules} WHERE id = ? [array ( 0 => '2', )] Error code: invalidrecord Stack trace: line 1403 of /lib/dml/moodle_database.php: dml_missing_record_exception thrown line 1379 of /lib/dml/moodle_database.php: call to moodle_database->get_record_select() line 7073 of /lib/accesslib.php: call to moodle_database->get_record() line 221 of /mod/mootyper/view.php: call to context_module::instance() I have no idea what has changed in Moodle so drastically or since when this issue exist. So if somebody can clearify this it would be awesome.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: this is because you are giving a course id to a context which is expecting a course module id. course ids should only be used for context_course::instance() Cheers
Comment 2: Oh.. thanks. But this means that I've had this error all along..
Comment 3: Yes, probably, but can be not noticeable, specially on low ranged IDS : as IDs are pure scalars, it is quite natural that your moodle have at least some courses (say ID 1 (SITE), 2, 3, 4, 5 ...) and have also course modules idntified by id 1, 2, 3, 4 ..... You may be able to notice it much later, when some data has been removed from your moodle, making holes in ID sequences that raise the error.
Comment 4: Ok.. I think I've fixed this in multiple areas of my plugin and I created a new version(2.6). Thanks for clearing that up..

Forum Post: 
Post title: Hook for authentication plugin to be able to revive suspended users.
Post description: I have an authentication plugin which is suspending user if they get deactivated/suspended in an external program similar to DB auth plugin . If a user gets reactivated in the external program, I would like to reactivated them through my authentication plugin as well during the login process. Right now I have a cron which activates them back at midnight but it would be nice if I could do it more instantly and reduce a couple tech support calls. I made a proposal in the Moodle Tracker https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-53306 Marina was suggesting a more generic approach for the hook. Let me know what you would like to see and I'm open to any suggestions. Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I fail to see exactly what it is that you can not do here? Using the current API you could implement in your plugin something like this: 
```text
class aaa extends auth_plugin_base {




    public function user_login($username, $password) {


        // Check if user exists and if it is enabled in external storage


        // if it is enable it here


        //


        //
```
Comment 2: ```text
If the user is suspended, Moodle will throw an "AUTH_LOGIN_SUSPENDED" error before calling the user_login function in my auth plugin.


Even if I move the call before the suspended check my user_login function cannot change the $user object to prevent the error call afterwards.
```
Comment 3: Than you are going the wrong way about it. If an external system is central user authority it should be able to communicate to Moodle that a user is enabled or disabled. That means: Create web service in your authentication plugin through which external system can enable or disable users (*) Whenever user status is modified external system calls web service method and updates user status * Even though core web service method core_user_update_users already exists it does not offer support for modifying suspended status of a specific user.
Comment 4: The authentication plugin architecture is a central piece of the login process. It should have a way of processing the user object before Moodle starts throwing any authentication error.
Comment 5: You seem to have a lot of time for your project. The process of including new feature (and what you ask for is definitely new feature) into Moodle core is long and perilous. Every new feature seldom passes opening of an issue in a tracker. Unless you are willing to provide finished code change and lobby to get it accepted I highly doubt anything will happen. To paraphrase New Testament - "Yes, I tell you again, it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for someone's new feature request to enter the Moodle core.'"
Comment 6: That seems like an oversight rather than a design.... But, what it means is that the "suspended" field in Moodle is restricted to be managed by Moodle only, keeping it as a way of disabling logins even from auth plugins. What you may want to do is use an alternate field for "suspended" that is used by your auth plugin alone. Then you can manage it any way you want. mike
Comment 7: The more I look at that, the more I think that is a bug; or at least something that was not considered. I think it makes sense to allow auth plugins to determine if and how they would want to deal with suspended users. I don't think it needs to be a "hook" necessarily, but perhaps a function that can be provided. I'll make comments in the issue you raised. mike
Comment 8: I added my thoughts to the tracker issue. Basically: Okay. Looking at the code, I think
we need to add a new function to "authlib", and then change the way
suspended users are handled in "authenticate_user_login". Currently,
suspended users are handled before any other checking. Instead, defer
that to when the user authentication method has been determined, and
allow the plugin to deal with suspensions, if it chooses. The default
would be as it is now. I worked up a concept here - https://github.com/moodle/moodle/compare/MOODLE_30_STABLE...POETGroup:MDL-53306_MOODLE_30_STABLE mike

Forum Post: 
Post title: Context menu in Atto?
Post description: Is there a plan to add context menu to Atto? If not, I'd like to throw this idea here. The way I see it, the menu will hold the standard options (copy,paste etc...) as well as item specific options. For example, right clicking a link will show edit/remove link options. The implementation would be in the plugins, where each plugin will have the menu options in its definition - something that is already halfway done in the tags attribute the plugins have. Another plus is the motoric accessibility it provides for users that cannot use a mouse and so on.
