Comment 6: Did you bump the version of your plugin, and go to the Site Administration > Notifications page?  Moodle will not recognize new event handlers until it goes through the install/upgrade process for plugins.
Comment 7: Well, events should be documented in the db/events.php file of the plugin that declares them. That file has to define an array giving details of the events you want to be notified about. It should also contain comments explaining all the events your plugin raises, and what the corresponding event data is. E.g. https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/quiz/db/events.php
Comment 8: Hi Tim, I am working out this on assignment module and my mod/assign/db/events.php file has event definition as below, $handlers = array( 'assessable_file_uploaded' => array ( 'handlerfile'      => '/mod/assign/locallib.php', 'handlerfunction'  => 'assessable_file_uploaded_handler',    // argument to call_user_func(), could be an array 'schedule'         => 'instant', 'internal'         => 0, ), ); My handler function is placed in mod/assign/locallib.php. Still the function is not recognised. I simulated the logic of sending notication to graders (teachers)  in order to send notification to admins. if ($admins = $this->get_admins()) { foreach ($admins as $admin) { $this->send_notification($user, $admin, 'gradersubmissionupdated', 'assign_notification', $submission->timemodified); } } return true; } The function get_admins function is not fetching the admins list? Do I need a change of approach here to send email notification to admins. Thanks and regards, Ramesh.
Comment 9: I'm afraid I cannot debug your code for you. Events elsewhere in Moodle work. Your event handing does not work. You need to investigate and work out what the problem is.
Comment 10: Hii Tim, I am a Php Developer and I am recently working on moodle so pls can you guide me about the db/event.php ,I m not getting that why its is essential to use handler array... $handlers = array( 'user_created' => array ( 'handlerfile'     => '/local/welcome/event_handlers.php', 'handlerfunction' => 'send_welcome', 'schedule'        => 'instant', ), ); Thanks, Mansha Maurya
Comment 11: I am not sure what you mean when you ask "why its is essential to use handler array?" If you are asking "Why is it essential for a developer to use a hander array if they want to use events in their plugin?" - because your events code will only work if you do! If you are asking "Why does Moodle require developers to do this?" - Well, think about what the Moodle events system is trying to do. When a certain event happens, it must inform all the plugins that have asked to be told about that event. How does Moodle know which plugins those are? Well, the plugins that want events have to tell Moodle which ones they want. That is what this array is for.
Comment 12: Hi tim, Thank s for the informations. It really clear my doubts to proceed with moodle events. Thankyou Mansha
Comment 13: Hi Tim, I actually need you guidance for " Developing new plugins" I want to create a plugin which display a Hello World message pls show me a way from where I can start. Thank you, Mansha
Comment 14: What have your web searches located so far (to avoid us duplicating your existing knowledge)

Comment 8: Also if you're wanting different date formats the langconfig.php language file has lots of strings that you can pass to userdate to get language appropriate formats so instead of 
```text
$my_date = date('m/d/y', strtotime($myuser->sd));
```
 do: 
```text
$my_date = userdate(
$myuser->sd)
, get_string('strftimedatefullshort', 'langconfig');
```
 This means it will flip to being M/D/Y if the user is using American English language pack or D/M/Y if they're using English English (if the language pack is installed and set).

Forum Post: 
Post title: lib/setup.php interfering with CURL request
Post description: Part of my MOODLE application sends a CURL request to an external server to get some user information. This request gets a successful response when run  with require_once(dirname(__FILE__) . '/lib/setup.php') commented out. However when run with this line open the POST data is being encoded to html entities by something in setup.php i.e. "variable=a&aa" would become "variable=a&aa" - which is causing the post to fail. Does anyone have any ideas what might be causing this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Looks like I was prematurely posting as have worked out what was happening - but will post anyway in case someone comes across a similar problem. MOODLE 2.7 /lib/setup.php line 707 
```text
// Configure ampersands in URLs



ini_set('arg_separator.output', '&');
```
 This was causing the ampersands in CURL POST data to be converted to HTML entities. To resolve I have added `ini_set('arg_separator.output', '&');` to the file that makes the CURL request.
Comment 2: So glad you posted this! I had this same exact problem. I thought the server was rejecting my POST request...
Comment 3: I'm not sure this is the best solution. Note that there are many places in Moodle core where cURL is used (via our tiny `new curl()` class wrapper) and there is no need to amend this PHP ini variable.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Using the Access API within a Local Plugin
Post description: I'm developing a plugin that adds a menu icon to Moodle's navigation bar (left of the notifications & messages menus, in v3).  The best way I could find to add it was with jQuery, using myplugin_extend_navigation() as a trigger to run: 
```text
$PAGE->requires->js_call_amd('myplugin/myjscode', 'init', array($myparam))
```
 That seems to work fine for me, but this context seems to be restricting what I want to do next. I'd like the menu to be rendered differently for admin users, vs. student or teacher users.  Since there isn't a simple isAdmin property to check, I've used the Access API to check the permissions on an action that I assume only admins can take.  This code has been working in my dev environment: 
```text
$isAdmin = has_capability('moodle/site:manageblocks', context_module::instance(1) );
```
 The problem is that not every environment will have a context module with the ID 1.  So, I started looking for ways to check for valid module IDs. A module can get the $cm argument from _extend_navigation() , but a local plugin only gets $nav . $PAGE->cm is also empty. Are there other options to identify admin users in this case?  Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ryan, this is not really what you asked for, but might help you: If you don't insist to add this menu icon at runtime with JQuery, the *_render_navbar_output() callback function (see https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Output_callbacks#render_navbar_output ) which you can add to your plugin's lib.php might help you. Within this function, you can check your capabilities and output plain HTML which will then be added to the navbar right where you described it. See https://moodle.org/plugins/local_navbarplus for a plugin of my colleague Kathrin as an example how to use this callback function. And, if you think your usecase could fit into our plugin, don't hesitate to create a ticket on Github to discuss it further. PS: If you want to check if the user is an admin, have a look at the is_siteadmin() function. Thanks, Alex
Comment 2: Thanks. I had seen is_siteadmin() , but the documentation had convinced me that using it was a bad idea.  Do you think the warning is overblown? It is strongly discouraged to use is_siteadmin() in activity modules, please use standard capabilities and enrolment status instead. The *_render_navbar_output() suggestion is a good one, but my larger goal is actually to build a tool that can plug into many different platforms, so for me, it makes more sense for the rendering code to be reusable (in JavaScript ).
Comment 3: Capabilities are definitely prefered over blanket is_siteadmin() checks - but the question really comes down to how do you control who should see the different links. If the icon is one that should be visible to anyone who has the ability to make configuration changes in the specific context of the page you are looking at (e.g. the icon is related to making changes to the configuration of the specific forum activity you are looking at), then there should be a capability check in the relevant context. If the icon is one that should be visible to anyone who has the ability to manage particular configuration settings across the whole site, then a capability check should be done against a relevant capability in the context_system::instance() context. If the icon relates to something that only site admins should ever access, and which will never be delegated to another user via a system-wide role, then is_siteadmin() is a valid check to make Unfortunately, your description of how & why the icon is different for different user types is a bit vague, so I can't give more insight than the above.
Comment 4: That makes sense. Sounds like is_siteadmin() will work for me.  Thanks!
Comment 5: If you simply want to check if someone is an admin for the whole site, then is_siteadmin() will tell you (without any need for context checks). Similarly, you can check for the sitewide capability 'moodle/site:config', via: has_capability('moodle/site:config', context_system::instance()). (The two of these are NOT the same - site admins have every capability automatically, it is possible to create and allocate a site-wide user role with moodle/site:config, but without other capabilities). If you want to find out if a person has certain editing privileges in a particular context, then you are going to need to know the context. Whilst local_myplugin_extend_navigation($nav) does not include details of the page context, the function local_myplugin_extend_settings_navigation($nav, $context) does include the context and, to the best of my knowledge, is also called on all pages.

Post title: Migrated Moodle site thinks installation is in progress/required
Post description: I recently inherited a Moodle installation that has been largely ignored for a long time (or so I'm told).  I know basically nothing about Moodle development/administration, but I know my way around PHP and server /db administration. The previous developer left nothing behind in terms of documentation or help at all, so I'm trying to get this installation running locally so I can start to work on it. I have the db and code copied to a local VM , pretty straight forward, everything should be fine, but for some reason when I try to access the site locally, it takes me to the "configure your main administrator account" screen, part of installation.  So for some reason, the site thinks it needs to be installed still, or finish being installed or something.  The db and code I have are from the production site, which runs fine.  So I'm wondering what I'm missing. I'm hoping some of you can point me to what checks Moodle does to decide whether or not installation is complete, or give me some idea of why it thinks it needs an admin account, when it should already exist. Hopefully that's enough to go on. Thanks! Oh, according to version.php in the code, the version is 2015051105.03
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There's also the moodledata directory.   Need that as well on the local. Check the variables in config.php file of the code on local.  They must reflect current environment.   After you get it to respond and can login, you'll need to run the search and replace tool.   Moodle doesn't do relative addressing but, rather, every internal URL uses the variable in config.php to build links.   Search for old site ... replace with local site. In the VM check that you can actually login to the local MySQL DB server using credentials from the config.php file from the command line/other My SQL tool. 'spirit of sharing', Ken
Comment 2: Thanks Ken. A little more context : I've set the config according to my local environment, and for the record, I didn't even change the domain , I'm just using a local hosts file to resolve the original domain locally, so domain references in the db and the config should be ok.   The site responds locally in that I can hit the domain locally and get to the site, but I can't actually log in because for whatever reason it thinks it's not fully installed yet. DB access does not appear to be the problem.  I know the creds work and the config is set accordingly and there are no errors related to db access.  The only indication of a problem is that the site doesn't go to the main page, doesn't load the custom theme, etc. I did make the assumption that the data directory was not required to be copied from the production server.  I figured it was just dynamically created based on the configuration, so I assumed it would recreate whatever it needs, but that could very well be the problem in this case.  So I'll get a copy of that and see how it goes from there. Thanks for the feedback.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Develop Moodle 1.9 theme in 2.9
Post description: Hello, I need to build a brand new custom moodle 1.9 theme. I have failed to create a moodle 1.9 website that functions. Should I choose to develop a new theme in the latest version of moodle, will it be compatible with moodle 1.9? Alternatively, can someone suggest how I might easily create a moodle 1.9 environment?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle 2.9 themes are not at all compatible with Moodle 1.9. You probably don't have much control over the situation, but Moodle 1.9 is now completely unsupported - no bug fixes, no security fixes and (in pretty much all cases) no fixes from 3rd-part plugin developers to support it. The first thing that should happen is for the site you are working with to upgrade to Moodle 2.9 (via Moodle 2.2). As for setting up Moodle 1.9, it should be more or less the same as setting up a Moodle 2.9 site. As a quick experiment, I just tried an install based on some M1.9 code I had lying around and it worked fine, apart from a few debugging warnings, on the same dev box I've got all my other Moodle sites on (in case it helps: Debian Linux + Apache webserver + PHP 5.6 + MySQL 5.5.44).
Comment 2: Not only did themes change entirely between Moodle1.9 and Moodle2.0 but they have been constantly developing and improving with every version since then. So no, as Davo says, you cannot create a 1.9 theme on Moodle2.x You can set up 1.9 in the same way as 2.x on a local computer to develop a theme. You may then be able to find some useful themes in the OLD themes list https://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?id=6552 and old 1.9 themes documentation at https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Themes_1.9 However, please bear in mind that both Moodle1.9 and its themes are unsupported and the best solution to your issue, as Davo suggests, would be to get the site upgraded - both for the sake of the features, the support and also the security fixes that have gone on over the last few years.

Forum Post: 
Post title: ES6 support in grunt uglify?
Post description: Hi, I'm looking at using a 3rd-party JS library in a plugin, but it uses ES6 - which isn't supported by the version of uglify set in package.json for M3.3 - it chokes with parse errors on the new syntax. Fortunately, there's a ES6 compatible "harmony" branch of UglifyJS , which is compatible. Changing package.json from 
```text
"grunt-contrib-uglify": "1.0.1",
```
 to 
```text
"grunt-contrib-uglify": "gruntjs/grunt-contrib-uglify#harmony",
```
 ...and running `npm update` fixes the parse errors, and is presumably backwards-compatible - unfortunately I can't run Behat at the moment to run check for regressions. Would I be right in thinking that grunt-contrib-uglify will need to merge their ES6 support into their main release, before Moodle can adopt it? Cheers, Dave.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As it turns out, I can probably just use Babel to transpile the lib to something that Moodle's Uglify is happy with. Updates to ES6 can happen (much) later on.

Post title: Get userid of logged in user
Post description: Hi i am using moodle 2.7+. i want to take logged users information . So i have created another folder inside moodle folder. Then i created one page test.php. I written code inside it. Code is shown below. <?php Global $USER,$COURSE; echo "test test"; $myuser=$USER->id; echo $myuser; //$myuser=$USER->username; //echo $myuser; $mycourse=$COURSE->title; echo $mycourse; ?> But it doesnot display nothing. I am logged and accessed this page.please help me
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Start with require_once(__DIR__ . '/../config.php');
Comment 2: Thanks tim. I tried but still not displaying anything. Can you check my code <?php echo "test test"; require_once(__DIR__ . '/../config.php'); Global $USER,$COURSE; echo "test test"; $myuser=$USER->id; echo $myuser; //$myuser=$USER->username; //echo $myuser; $mycourse=$COURSE->title; echo $mycourse; ?> The first echo is working. But the second one is not working
Comment 3: The first thing to try in this situation is to add the following immediately after the <?php tag: 
```text
ini_set('display_startup_errors',1);


ini_set('display_errors',1);


error_reporting(-1);
```
 This will make sure that full error reporting is on before it runs any code (you could also check your web server log for errors). The most likely explanation, if the code is failing that early, is you have the wrong path to config.php. The require_once line, above, assumes your code is in a subdirectory below where config.php is located (e.g. if config.php is in 'moodle/' and your script is, for example in 'moodle/local/'). If your script is in the same directory as config.php, then the line should be: require_once(__DIR__.'/config.php'); If the script is two subdirectories below config.php (e.g. 'moodle/local/myplugin/'), then it should be: require_once(__DIR__.'/../../config.php');
Comment 4: Have you tried $COURSE->fullname instead of $COURSE->title?
Comment 5: Following other posts that had to be removed because of security issues and from PMs from 'moodle learner', this code was being added directly to the moodle config.php - so: 1. [Copied from thread that was deleted to remove insecure info] For what its
worth - if you want to display those echo lines, you probably need to
put them into one of your theme layout files not in the config.php.
Also, I don't think there is a $COURSE->title, there is
$COURSE->fullname and $COURSE->shortname 2. In most cases - unless requested by someone in the thread (e.g. to provide secure information such as log in details to help with the support) - help should be requested through the forums, where more people with expertise can contribute, rather than via PM to an individual. Personally speaking, I am not able to provide support via PM, except in rare cases relating to my own themes/plugins (and even then would recommend going through the forum/plugin page).

Post title: how to get a course with Moodle API
Post description: I want to create an application that can read the course of Moodle. and I want to use a Moodle API. may I ask the steps how to read the Moodle API? Can I have one example of PHP applications that use the API moodle?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Programming and learning to program the Moodle API is a steep curve. If you want to deal with courses - after having studied  the whole developer documentation - you could start with my uploadusersandcourses.php which is meant to create new courses and enroll people at the same time, either through the Web-GUI of Moodle either as nightly cron job. You may also look at everything you can find in Moodle's php directories, especially in /course/ directory Best thing is always to search for existing code, either in Moodle's php directories or in the modules & plugins database here. Sometimes you will find code examples also in these forums. Then use that existing code and modify it step by step to make it do what you want to do yourself. Starting from scratch is hardly possible. Rosario
Comment 2: Hi, I want to get the list of courses using category id which the course mapped to. currently we have the api to get the course using course id. any suggestion would be grateful. Thanks
Comment 3: Then please have a look at the "useful sql queries" posts here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=153059 Using these sql queries you can display first the data you want to collect and see in your phpMyAdmin or any other Database -Management-Tool of the database you use. Once this works, you can start to program it in php. But at this point, if you want to integrate it in the Moodle Web-GUI, you will have different options: you put your php-file in the yourMoodlePhpDir/admin and protect it with the necessary Moodle-API-functions so that only site admins can execute it. See as example search.php in that directory. In such a php-file you can use any desired HTML output and any Moodle-API-sql-query-functions you develop a block in which you can display your output you develop a special module you can place in yourMoodlePhpDir/local. See for reference my uploadusersandcourses.php and use only the header lines and all needed files to create your own module. Then insert the lines of code you need to make your query and display your output Rosario
Comment 4: where I can see the file uploadusersandcourses.php ?
Comment 5: In these forums here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=128317 You can also study the file /course/externallib.php in your own Moodle-Php-Directory where you can find a function get_course_contents() This function is pretty complicated to understand, but it returns the whole content of a course which might be closer to what you are planning to do. Here is a crossreference site if you prefer browsing on the web instead of your own Moodle-Php-Dir: http://www.sourcexref.com/xref/moodle/nav.html?_functions/index.html (Moodle 2.4) http://xref-diff.mukudu-dev.net/moodle26 (Moodle 2.6) I still am not sure what you intend to do exactly. If you want to create a list of courses, e.g. for navigation purposes, you can use my sitenavigation block. You will find it in the modules&plugins database. It is a block to display categories and courses in nested folders. There are a lot of Admin options to set up that block. If you need navigation, you could use it as is. If you need something else, you could study the code in there and take what you need. Rosario

Post title: Output renderer issue
Post description: Hello Folks, Please I was wondering if anyone has had this type of error message come up on a moodle site without any changes made to it. "Parse error: syntax error, unexpected '[' in /usr/local/apache2/htdocs/mysite-moodle/lib/outputrenderers.php on line 110". I just want to be sure first before making attempts to check the code in the renderer.php page. Any help will be appreciated please. Regards
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Folks, Users are unable to log onto our website. We have a problem with the outputrenderer.php file. Our
moddle site was working well on a fresh installation of moodle 3.0.
Users didn't have any problem logging in. No changes were made to it at
any time and everything had been runing well. Suddenly, when we visit the
site ( http://kassop.nuguide-vle.com/ ), we only get the error message below. " Parse error : syntax error, unexpected '[' in /usr/local/apache2/htdocs/mywebsite-moodle/lib/outputrenderers.php on line 110 " In my attempt to fix the error, I opened the outputrenderers.php and line 110 has the code below. "' pragmas' => [Mustache_Engine::PRAGMA_BLOCKS])); " My php text editor actually highlights that line in red. Could someone advise me on what to do to resolve this issue, please? Your help will be very much appreciated.
Comment 2: In looking at the code of that file on a functioning system, one sees the following: 'pragmas' => [Mustache_Engine::PRAGMA_BLOCKS])); Note the difference in yours above ... yours begins with a " then a tick '. Yours also ends with a " Unless you posted in italics the line and the forum editor added the whole line enclosed in ""'s. Syntax error indicates a mis-match   The ['s should be there, but because of the "'s surrounding the entire line PHP objects. So if your code has " at the beginning of that line and an enclosing " at the end, remove those characters and save the file. Total guess of course. 'spirit of sharing', Ken
Comment 3: Odd.  The line is now 112: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blame/MOODLE_30_STABLE/lib/outputrenderers.php#L112 - I suggest that you check the code above to see if that is different too or download a new fresh latest M3.0.
Comment 4: It looks like you are using a version of PHP that is so old that it does not recognise the array literal syntax (  [1, 2, 3] ) that was added in PHP 5.4. Moodle has required at least PHP 5.4 since the Moodle 2.7 release, and the environment check will prevent it from installing on older PHP versions. So, probably a change was made to your side: someone changed the version of PHP being used to a very old one. That seems very strange.
Comment 5: Thanks everyone for your responses and suggestions. The problem has now been resolved. Those quotes and italics were added by me after I copied the line. Tim, you are perfectly right. We tried to fix this issue " It looks like you are using a version of PHP that is so old that it does not recognise the array literal syntax (  [1, 2, 3] ) that was added in PHP 5.4. " In the process, the quote below was apparent. "... So, probably a change was made to your side: someone changed the version of PHP being used to a very old one. That seems very strange. " That was exactly what happened.  The hosting company did something wrong and unprofessional without informing us about it. Our sites were strangely running PHP 5.3. It took us a lot of effort and previous tickets to prove it to them that our server had been running on PHP 5.4 and that was why we were able to run moodle 3.0 before everything went wrong with all our sites running it. Now all our moodle sites are running fine again as they have changed it to PHP 5.4.26. Once again, thanks to everyone.

Post title: Proposed change of mdl_user_preferences.value to TEXT
Post description: See MDL-46739 . Other similar columns like mdl_config.value and mdl_config_plugins.value are TEXT, so it is surprising that this column is different, and that suprise has lead to bugs in the past (see linked issues of that tracker issue). Obviously a TEXT column will be fractionally slower than a VARCHAR on some databases, but I don't think it will be significant. (User preferences for the current user are cached in the session.) Anyway, just though I ought to publicise that proposed change. Comments welcome.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Large scale moodle installations 30.000+ users - tips?
Post description: Hi, I have been reading here and around the web, on which precautions to make when making a large scale moodle. We are counting on 30.000 - 60.000 users, and that will of cause take its toll on the server (s). But which measurements are we talking about? Do we need a cluster of servers to run the site and another to run the database ? Do we need one big monster machine to run the site and another to run the database. Do we need one Big monster only to minimize mysql hang-load time. There are many different suggestions, but i like to hear from those who has experience in such a large scale solution. What are the requirements, for the hardware? I hope you can help. Thanks, kind regards Henrik Sune Pedersen
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hej Henrik, the total number of users is not necessarily an indication of how big your setup has to be, it is mainly about concurrency. I used to run an 85k users, 500 concurrent (as in simultaneous) off one server (48Gb memory 24 CPU threads). You will need to optimize everything, database, webserver, php, memcache to achieve the best performance. One big machine makes it easy to optimize and configure, however this can only scale up to a certain amount. A cluster scales (if done right) much further, but is much more complicated to optimize, and will give worse performance for the end user due to added latencies. For database there are essentially three hardware parameters that influence performance: Memory Disk IOPS CPU Good luck! David
Comment 2: Thank you for your answer. I will try to remember to post the solution in here when the project is done.

Post title: Add custom licenses to file picker
Post description: I'm looking to add a list of custom licenses in the file picker, as discussed in this post: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=206212 I'd like to create a local plugin for this, but unsure of the best way to approach this and would certainly appreciate any pointers. Here's what I've done so far: 1. Reviewed https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=355789 and https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Tutorial Local development environment (Vagrant) is set up Code checker and PHPDoc plugins are installed 2. Reviewed https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Local_plugins it's not clear to me which files are required and which are optional unsure of which file I would use to build this functionality - settings.php, maybe? 3. Installed and reviewed similar plugin https://moodle.org/plugins/local_listcoursefiles it's close, but I need for the plugin to handle the addition of the license https://github.com/innocampus/moodle-local_listcoursefiles/blob/master/README.md#adding-a-new-license I think I still have a lot more reading ahead of me, but was hoping you might be able to help get me going in the right direction.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I don't know much about this specific thing - I've never added a custom licence - but a couple of the questions I can answer: The only required files in a local plugin are version.php and lang/en/PLUGINNAME.php (the top two in https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Plugin_files ). Depending on the version of Moodle you're developing on you might need an empty lib.php to stop it complaining / breaking. The only string definition you strictly need in the language file is: $string['pluginname'] = 'Whatever you want to call your plugin'; The code from Rex Lorenzo's post in the discussion you link to looks like it's intended to be put into db/upgrade.php. You can't just copy the code in though - there's a bunch of boilerplate required in upgrade.php (see https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Upgrade_API ), and it needs to correspond to your plugin version in version.php Hope that helps!
Comment 2: Very helpful! Thank you Michael!

Post title: backup_release and backup_version in mdl_config
Post description: Using MSSQL 2008 R2 with $dbtype = 'ms sql ', I upgraded a Moodle version 2.0.4 site to Moodle version 2.9.1. After the upgrade was done I ran the following command in the Moodle database : 
```text
SELECT


   id,


   name,


   value


FROM mdl_config


WHERE name LIKE '%release%'


OR name LIKE '%version%'


ORDER BY name
```
 It returns this data: 
```text
id    name    value


3142    allversionshash    xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx


239    backup_release    2.0


238    backup_version    2010111800


240    blocks_version    2007081300
```
 What do the backup_release and backup_version rows mean? What is a "backup_release" and a "backup_version"? Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There have been various changes to the structure of course backup files over the years, so these are to keep track of which one a backup was made with. They're saved in the backup data file.

Forum Post: 
Post title: admin setting
Post description: hey guys, i have 2 questions about admin stings , 1- can we disable cache when we use  "admin_setting_configtext()" method? 2- is it allow which directly insert record in "config_plugins" table ?? thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 1. I'm not really sure what cache you are wanting to disable - when using that function on a settings page, saving the form will clear the cache. 2. If you want to insert a record in config_plugins, then call set_config('setting name', 'value', 'mypluginname') - don't insert directly in the database as that will break the caching of variables.
Comment 2: Thanks for your reply . for the first part i must say , i manually update it (configtext) field in DB , and when i check the field in setting , its still show previous data which is belong cache , (when i purge cache , will be fine), as i need to update a field , is that any method to update like "set_config" as you have said for inserting? thanks
Comment 3: set_config() is the method for inserting a new entry in the mdl_config_plugins table - there is no other method provided by Moodle for doing so (there is certainly not another function call for clearing the config cache - that would be pointless as there is already the set_config() function that sets the value and updates the cache).
Comment 4: so what ,if we want to update a record? let say when we insert a setting by text field [admin_setting_configtext] , since we dont change first argument of this method , it will update same record, so let say i want to do same thing in the code, instead of inserting , just updating the record ? does moodle provide any function? otherwise i should manually  update  and clear cache.
Comment 5: I'm not really sure how many other ways I can put this. If you want to insert / update / delete a record in mdl_config_plugins, use set_config() - don't manually access that DB table as this will mean the cache will be out of date. You can look at the code for it if you really want - it's all available here: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/moodlelib.php#L1383 As you can clearly see from the code - if there is no entry for that config setting, then a new record will be inserted, if there is an existing value, then it will be updated and if the value you are setting is null, then the existing record will be deleted or not inserted (as appropriate).

```text
$coursecontext = context_course::instance($courseid, MUST_EXIST);
```
 without any explicit library requirement. But we would need to know more about your issue to provide more helpful answer.

Post title: Customizing the user Registration Form
Post description: Hi all, I'm building out a new product on a shiny new Moodle 2.0 installation, and I'm hoping to keep the core as clean as possible. Unfortunately, my very first task is making me butt heads with this goal. I need to make some significant changes to the Moodle Registration form. The first is to allow multiple users to share an email address. The second is to require a unique code in order to register for the site and another to register for a specific course. Additionally, I need to set up a second registration form that will allow registered users to add another course using a username, password, and unique course code. I'm looking for a way to integrate the registration form into my authentication plugin or to override the registration form by some other means. Is it possible to override the registration form without editing it directly? I'm certainly open to solutions I've not yet considered, but the parameters of my problem are set by the client and I have little to no sway in that regard. Thanks for your time, Chriis
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I figured out a way to solve all of the issues that I've mentioned here. 1. Disable the registration form. Log in as an administrator, click Site Administration->Plugins->Authentication and disable self registration. (We'll use our own self registration plugin so the default needs to go away for now). 2. Build a block called "enrollment" which will go on the front page . All it has is a couple links. One of them goes to the new student enrollment (registration) form. The other is for existing students. 3. Build a local plugin (also called enrollment). Put both of the enrollment forms in here. I copied and pasted the sign up form and will be editing from there.
Comment 2: Hi, I'm currently trying to achive the same customization of the enrolment form...I'm just wondering if I can have a look the block & local plugin's you created? I've followed your steps and I can't get it working :/ Thanks in advanced!
Comment 3: While the steps I placed here were working for me, I found that I was much better off moving my local plugin into the enrol plugin. So here's a bit more detail as to what I've done: 1. I have a custom authorization plugin that is very heavily based on the db authorization plugin. It just has a couple of changes to methods that populate the $USER global so that I have access to it when automatically enrolling users into courses (actually goups). 2. I have a block called "enrollment." Which consists of nothing more than block_enrollment.php (attached), version.php and the necessary lang files. All the block does is provide a couple of links. It is set up to hide if a user is logged in. If you want it to actually show up on the home page, you have to login as an admin (or someone with sufficient permissions), turn on editing, and place it on the page. 3. I created an enrol plugin (attached) and copied ~/login/signup.php and ~/login/signup_form.php into the new enrol plugin. I renamed this to existing_signup.php existing_signup_form.php and copied those files to create new_signup.php and new_signup_form.php. I created a lib.php file where I extended the enrol_plugin class and added a method called enrol_student which throws the student into the appropriate course. I made several edits to the signup forms in order to leverage the exact actions that I wanted. 4. There was some configuration that needed to happen on the group and course level to ensure that users were allowed to self-register. I can't remember every detail of the configuration so if you have any problems please post here and I'll try to get answers to you.
Comment 4: Hi Chris. I've been reading through this very interesting thread as its something I too have been dabbling with for a while. We too seem to have fairly specific requirements of course access and the signup procedure, which has resulted in me needing to customise my Moodle installation quite a bit. I have been desperately trying to be doing changes as "cleanly" as possible, so that I have no issues when I upgrade the main Moodle core. So far I have managed two updates (2.0 -> 2.1.x -> 2.2.x) without any significant issues. Our basic requirement is that our courses have guest access to allow students to have a look around before deciding if they want to take the course. After this, if they are interested they have to go to a specific signup page just for that course which has a few custom questions or dropdown selction options which just relate to that course. On some courses, the students also have to enter a unique invitation code (not a common one). The way we manage this at the moment is that we have each course running in a dedicated theme. In these themes, I have changed the general.php file, removing links to the standard Moodle login page and instead I link users to a simple customised login page for the course that also has a link to a dedicated external signup form. This form then populates the standard Moodle signup form along with the standard moodle user fields and a few custom fields. After this a normal 'email-based self registration' takes place for that user (with a confirmation email etc.) just as if the user had filled out the original Moodle signup form himself. On most courses, when we post the form data, we also populate an external database with the username and coursename which we basically use only to invisibly matriculate that user later. So far this option has worked alright, though I don't really like it as it's a bit messy. The development was a bit "ad-hoc", and as usual we kept changing our minds as we were going along. I really prefer the option you have laid out here with a special enrollment block that has the links to your customised forms which are a part of your customised enrolment plugins. In my context , I could work on that, and expand the funcionality of this plugin so that I have either seperate forms in the plugin (for the different courses) or seperate enrolment plugins. However, what I can't really understand is how the enrolment plugin works, and  how it interacts with your custom authorization plugin. I have downloaded the enrolment plugin that you posted here, copied it into my enrol directory. I then manage to install it, activate it in my "Manage enrol plugins" page, but then I can't seem to get it working beyond that. When I navigate to the forms, I get an error saying "Authentication plugin not found". Any ideas what I am missing? I would be really grateful if you could give me a hand. Likewise, if anybody has any other tips or ideas based on my specific requirements as listed above, please let me know. Thanks a lot!
Comment 5: Hello Chriis,, I want to create Role field (like student,Teacher,Parents,Corp-orator) on the registration page so that we can assign the task to the respective guys at the time of registration. So if it is possible then please let me know how i create that field. Thanks & Regard Amit
Comment 6: Sounds like you just need to define a user profile field: https://docs.moodle.org/en/User_profile_fields This will not set the 'role' in for the user, in terms of capabilities granted (because, in Moodle, roles are usually given per-course, rather than to a user account across a whole site). You can, however, write some code that will trigger when the user is created (via the 'user_created' event) and then do something based on the value of this user profile field.
Comment 7: Hello Smith, Thanks for response, I followed your guide and i have created Role field on Registration page. I want to write coding for the Roles which i defined,so can you let me know from where i have to start the coding and what step i have to follow for the coding. If possible then give some brief idea so i can do coding part.

There's a custom menu on topic 0 to allow the learner to jump to any paticular topic. My client wants to know if there's a way to represent on that front menu (by way of a tick icon, etc) if a "topic" is completed, by which is meant "if all completable activities in a given topic are completed". Is there a way for me to find this out using a built in objects, or am I going to have to get crazy with the database myself?


```text
moosh course-enrolleduser 12969


moosh version 0.23


No command provided, possible commands:


...
```
 
```text
﻿
moosh course-list test


!!! Error reading from 
database
 !!!
```
 I'm running moosh as the webserver user and I have had to set the home directory to the dataroot directory since that's the only place where the webserver user can write to. None of the webserver's files are owned by the webserver user. I have similar problems trying to run this as the root user. So I'm not sure if my problems are because of permissions problems or because maybe Moosh doesn't really work, or their documentation on moosh-online.com is out of date. Any help?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, Each moosh command is coded separately - how well it works across different Moodle versions - it varies. I need to know what version of Moodle are you using. The easiest for me would be if you raise an issue on github . In case of output like: 
```text
﻿moosh course-list test


!!! Error reading from database !!!
```
 turn the debug on first (e.g. in config.php), so you can capture the exact error and stack trace. cheers, Tomek
Comment 2: We've got it installed on a system with a moodle 2.8 and 3.1 installation running. The permissions are really weird. I have to run it as apache, but the apache user has no home directory, so I set HOME to the dataroot. Other than that, it seems that the documentation on commands is out-dated or something else isn't set up correctly. And why would it run out of memory listing users for a course with less than 10 users?
Comment 3: Hi Diane, The permissions are really weird. I have to run it as apache, but the
apache user has no home directory, so I set HOME to the dataroot. The permissions are pretty important, seems like a good entry for FAQ - http://moosh-online.com/faq/#permissions . it seems that the documentation on commands is out-dated or something else isn't set up correctly. The documentation should be up to date but I keep http://moosh-online.com/commands/ up to date only for the latest version of the command - so it may happen that there is a difference between version for Moodle 2.8 and 3.1. It's very easy to edit the documentation - for example http://moosh-online.com/commands page is generated from https://github.com/tmuras/moosh/blob/master/www/commands/index.md . If you have any documentation improvements, please send them to me as pull request on github. Why would it run out of memory listing users for a course with less than 10 users? It should not. If you can provide more information and report an issue, so I can reproduce the problem - I may be able to fix it. cheers, Tomek

Comment 6: Yes, http://moosh-online.com/commands/#course-list refers to an old version of the command and should be updated. The search argument is really a part of the SQL you should provide to find the courses you're looking for. It will be injected after WHERE clause. For example to find all with "test" inside fullname you write: 
```text
moosh course-list 'fullname like "%test%"'
```
 
```text
vagrant@vagrant:/var/www/html/moodle$ moosh course-list --help
*** course-list ***
OPTIONS:
	-h, --help
		help information

	-n, --idnumber
		show idnumber

	-i, --id
		display id only column

	-c, --categorysearch=
		courses from given category id only

	-v, --visible=
		show all/yes/no visible

	-e, --empty=
		show only empty courses: all/yes/no

	-f, --fields=
		show only those fields in the output (comma separated)

	-o, --output=
		output format: tab, csv


ARGUMENTS:
	search ...
```

Forum Post: 
Post title: View all courses without categories
Post description: Hello, I'm searching a function to get all courses on Moodle without categories. I have never coded on Moodle and some indications would be very useful. Here my problem : 
```text
$chelper = new coursecat_helper();
```
 
```text
$chelper->set_show_courses(self::COURSECAT_SHOW_COURSES_EXPANDED)->


set_courses_display_options(array(


    'recursive' => true,


    'limit' => $CFG->frontpagecourselimit,


    'sort' => array('sortorder' => 0),


    'viewmoreurl' => new moodle_url('/course/index.php'),


    'viewmoretext' => new lang_string('fulllistofcourses'),


));
```
 In this way I see all the courses but they are sorted by the categories and if I filter for example by name it will be for each category and not for all the courses. This function exists or I need to create my sql request ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I find the function :D It's something like : 
```text
get_courses('all', "c.fullname ASC")
```
 And we can read it in course/externallib.php : 
```text
/**


 * Get courses


 *


 * @param array $options It contains an array (list of ids)


 * @return array


 * @since Moodle 2.2


 */


public static function get_courses($options = array()) {


....


}
```
Comment 2: After you have created a new course helper and set the display option by doing 
```text
$chelper = new coursecat_helper();

$chelper->set_show_courses(self::COURSECAT_SHOW_COURSES_EXPANDED)->

set_courses_display_options(array(

    'recursive' => true,

    'limit' => $CFG->frontpagecourselimit,

    'sort' => array('sortorder' => 0),

    'viewmoreurl' => new moodle_url('/course/index.php'),

    'viewmoretext' => new lang_string('fulllistofcourses'),

));
```
 you will need to fetch all courses by doing 
```text
$courses = coursecat::get(0)->get_courses($chelper->get_courses_display_options());
```
 it returns an indexed array of objects (key is courseid and value is course object). Then you can sort it using something like 
```text
arsort($courses);
```

Post title: Erro: Conexão com o banco de dados falhou
Post description: Estou instando o moodle 3.4 no wampserver 3  na hora de configurações da base de dados aparece o seguinte erro: Instalação - Moodle 3.4.1 (Build: 20180115) Erro: Conexão com o banco de dados falhou É possível que o banco de dados esteja sobrecarregado ou não está funcionando adequadamente O administrador do site também deve verificar se os dados do banco de dados foram corretamente especificados no config.php Warning : my sql i::__construct(): (HY000/1045): Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost' (using password: YES) in C:\wamp64\www\moodle\lib\dml\mysqli_native_moodle_database.php on line 79 Alguém pode me ajudar?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Olá, Flavio esse erro é comum na instalação quando você erra a senha para conectar no banco de dados. Veja que ali ele mostra a mensagem de erro bem clara: Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost' (using password: YES) Isso quer dizer que você configurou o Moodle para acessar o banco com o usuário "root" (sem aspas), forneceu uma senha e essa senha está errada. Note que esse fórum é dedicado à comunidade internacional e por isso se pede que escreva em inglês. No caso de dúvidas em português, sugiro procurar a Comunidade Brasileira aqui no Moodle.org Grande abraço!
Comment 2: Valeu Daniel, Resolvi o problema. Agora gostaria de saber se não tem algo desconto nos curso ofertado pela Adapta tenho muito interesse: Curso Moodle para Desenvolvedores em Brasília, março de 2018 Abraços

Post title: invalid action parameter
Post description: Hi Guys, I am new to moodle. I am having a problem adding my own activity module to my course. When I tried to add it it gives me /modedit,php blank page and then when tried to refresh the page it gives me an "Invalid action parameter" error. Does anyone here experiencing this problem? Best regards, Joel
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It will help if you provide a link where we can see the whole code of your module - ideally something like public Github repository. There will probably be an error in your lib.php, not view.php file. In any case, blank page is a typical symptom of thrown PHP error while displaying errors is disabled. Make sure to set the debugging level to the most verbose (DEBUG_DEVELOPER) value and let your Moodle/PHP display errors.
Comment 2: I have the same flag when I try to access the Course content from the Mobile app. error the param" is invalid. Every other thing seems perfect.
Comment 3: I haven't figured out the problem but I moved on by replacing all the plugin folders with folders from the moodle mobile master.

Post title: Firefox 32 and behat (warning!)
Post description: It appears that Firefox 32 (the latest version) is incompatible with Selenium 2.42.2 (again, the latest version): https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=7642 This means that it is probably a good idea to turn off Firefox automatic updates for a short time, if you rely on Behat tests as part of your development cycle. Hopefully Selenium 2.43.0 will be released soon, as that apparently has a fix (but the issue does not mention a release date for that version). Note: I've tried an earlier version of Selenium, which didn't help. I'm currently trying to pull the source code for selenium, in the hope that I'll be able to compile the fixed version myself.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: To update - compiling the selenium code myself ( https://code.google.com/p/selenium/source/checkout ) has fixed the problem - hopefully this might help someone else out ...
Comment 2: Davo, could you upload the selenium jar that you were able to build? I tried to compile the selenium code on my Mac and ran into this error:

 That is because somehow it managed to build the jar without a main class file so that the jar is executable. I also followed the steps at https://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/BuildingWebDriver and ran:

```text
./go //java/server/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/server:server:uber //java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium:client-combined:project
```

```text
no main manifest attribute, in selenium-java-2.42.2.jar
```
 I felt that I was so close on making this work this time.
Comment 6: Sorry, we actually found this issue here but I only posted locally about it. This might be useful so for info I've pasted below how to revert your Firefox version (which is a easier than compiling Selenium). Link is for Windows but there are presumably similar for other platforms. One other thing, if you are unsure what Firefox version you have, do not visit the about page to find out or it'll upgrade; turn automatic upgrade off first, as below. --sam This is a general problem; here's the bug reference . They have fixed it in Selenium 2.0.43, which is not out yet. So I recommend developers either don't upgrade Firefox, or use Chrome, until this new Selenium version comes out. If you have already upgraded Firefox it is possible to downgrade as follows: 1. In Firefox settings, go to Options / Advanced / Update and select 'Check for updates, but let me choose'. 2. Download Firefox 31 installer from here: https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/releases/31.0/win32/en-GB/ (Firefox Setup 31.exe). 3. Close Firefox and run the installer.
Comment 7: Under Linux, I actually found it easier to compile selenium ( git clone repo, run the 'go' script) than to replace the package-managed version of Firefox with an older version, but both options work.
Comment 8: Note that Selenium 2.43.1 has been released: http://selenium-release.storage.googleapis.com/2.43/selenium-server-standalone-2.43.1.jar
Comment 9: Yes. I upgraded last night, and I was getting weird errors when it tried to click on the Edit quiz link in the Quiz administration nav. Not sure if 2.43.1 is to blame, but if I might go back to 2.43.0, which seemed to work.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Two issues with "lock" for grade and grade category items
Post description: Hello, some teachers of the institution i work for found two issues with the "locked" field of a grade/category item. If you try to edit a category grade item, let's say, you change the max grade and also checks the "locked" checkbox, your maxgrade is edited but the item is not locked. Then you change just the locked status, save and it works. If you try to change the maxgrade again and at same time unlock the item, it works. I have not found an issue on tracker related to this. This is more problematic. You have a "locked" category item, the locked help text says: "If ticked, grades can no longer be automatically updated by the related activity. "  But if you change, let's say, maxgrades again, then the item is updated but the grades are not recalculated, because of the locked option. So, it is not only by the related activity, but any changes won't take effect until you unlock the item (settings areare stored and retrieved ok, but no changes to grades). So, this help message hides part of the problem. It may be somewhat related to MDL-48634 It seems this is not the expected behaviour. If the changes really should not be applied, then the form fields for other settings should be disabled when the item is locked. But it seems to be a difficult approach: what if you lock an item, save it, get back to it, unlock, change something, lock again and save? This way, the more appropriate behaviour would be to apply the changes and recalculate grades even if the items are locked, just for the item settings, not for the activities as is said on the help text. What do you think? Kind regards,

Forum Post: 
Post title: MUC identifiers, proposed change to implementation
Post description: Hi, During my implementation of MDL-53213 it realised that MUC identifiers can change the cache pointer of an existing cache eg; $properties = array('dbfamily' => 'pg sql '); $cache = cache::make('core', 'databasemeta', $properties); Then; $properties = array('dbfamily' => ' mysql '); $cache2 = cache::make('core', 'databasemeta', $properties); This will result in $cache = $cache2, which is not what I would have expected as a developer.  It feels dangerous and counter intuitive. Proposal: Identifiers and Sharing options be added to the definition_hash. Identifiers would not be able to be changed once a cache::make has been called.  You will need to complete a second cache::make if you need a different cache option set. Remove multikeyprefix.  This would be handled by the store as the singlekeyprefix along with the definition hash if that was interesting to the store.  Some may need it for keys, others may not as definition hashes will have separated it. This will then uniquely identify a cache by those things and the code above would result in two separate instances.  It also has a benefit of allowing developers to purge a cache based on that new definition.  So in the databasemeta case, I would just purge the pgsql cache, and not all of them.  Developers can then use this function to make identifiers like smaller sub-caches for certain use cases.  I've had a couple where I want the identifier to be a userid or forumid and manage it as a separate cache. Generate singlekeyprefix would then not be required, the singlekeyprefix is the definition hash. Then the way definition hash and key hash are handled should be pushed downwards into the store.  A reason for this is something like; Redis can uses hashes for each of the definitions. A filestore can do the same thing. Memcached would need to use a different strategy of prefixing the definition hash before the key_hash in a single key.  But it has to do that now.  It will still have all the same purge problems.  But other caches would no longer suffer from purging all versions of identifiers and sharing options when a cache is purged. There is currently very little documentation about the usefulness of identifiers and it's original intended use.  I have spend quite some time working on the caching code and still don't understand the purpose they were made for.  My idea above is much clearer to me. Possible future direction is also to push the calculation of the key into the store rather than the loader.  The store is the one that needs to handle restriction on the keyspace.  Whether it's size or character options available.  Each store could determine the best rules for it.  This coupled with the definition hash change would let a store decide how it indexes the content we send to it.  File stores can have directories, redis can have hashes, mongodb can do the same kind of thing.  Memory caches can just use keys as-is and memcached could put the keys together as it can't ensure unique keys without that. I would like feedback on whether others think this is a move in the right direction and if there are any objections or ideas around this proposal.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There has been not feedback on this over a reasonable amount of time.  I'm bumping this for a couple of reasons; 1. See if there can be any buy-in to the idea or comments on it. 2. It has come to my attention through MDL-53875 that session cache is broken and a perfect case for the use of identifiers. To try to explain 2 a little more; Session cache for users is just a set of elements split by session_id().  That is the same as a set of elements split by an identifier.  With the capability of the proposal above, you get session caches to be much more like application caches in terms of code and management.  In my view it would reduce the complexity of the code and provide more consistent interface for users.  As MDL-53875 shows, there isn't any testing around session cache that ensures it cleans up correctly or can find the right sessions to destroy.  Work on MDL-55604 also showed there is no testing around identifiers at this time and the reliability of them is only tested by some use of them in the databasemeta cache.  Some small amount of testing was added in MDL-55604 , however it is a complicated area.
Comment 2: I don't have the depth of experience with this to by able to offer much, other than saying what you are proposing sounds reasonable and safer, so I encourage you to go forward with it. On a general off topic note about MUC - since you seem to be working the most in this area, my personal feeling (without actual technical analysis) is that if we should be doing anything, we should actually be reducing the feature set of MUC and only allowing developers to do very performant operations with it. Anecdotally it seems there is so much functionality that many people don't know how to use and too often we are coming across MUC uses which are utilising its 'flexibility' at the cost of performance (e.g. serialisation impact). On reflection I think it would've been better to restrict the way which data which can be stored in MUC so it was as fast as possible rather than as flexible as possible.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle session timeout not being respected
Post description: I have a moodle installation (2.7.9) that used to work fine. When we deployed an IDM-sso solution ( Oracle Access Manager) that included a load balancer, our problems started. 1) First, a user that was authenticated correctly (using a custom built auth plugin) 2) When the user tries to post a forum message everything is ok 3) When a user starts writing the forum message and spends more than 120 seconds on that page and the clicks the post button he/she gets the message " Sorry, guests are not allowed to post." 4) When he/she clicks continue they are shown as logged in. I immediately started searching for session time out, and using a script, i figured out that moodle was throwing him out after ~120 seconds (session timeout is set in 2 hours). Sessions are handled in the DB ( MySQL ). When i printed the $SESSION var i got 
```text
object(stdClass)#69 (1) {
  ["has_timed_out"]=>
  bool(true)
}
```
 Any clues on what might be happening?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Christos, what is the logic/algo behind that load balancer? You should inspect the HTTP Request&Response to look for the clues about why the Moodle session will be considered as expired: everything is based on cookies on Moodle side and it could be possible that something is mangling those cookies after that period. HTH , Matteo
Comment 2: Hi Matteo, We are using Zenloadbalancer ( http://www.zenloadbalancer.com/ ) as part of an Oracle IAM and SSO solution we recently added to our infrastructure. You are probably right, that something is mangling those cookies, but i bypassed that by activating the ldap auth as a second auth solution, so i guess that after failing the first auth (IAM0 it moves to the next Ldap that actually works. I know that it is not the best solution, but it works. I will look more into this to figure out what is going on. Thank you for responding. Best regards, Christos
Comment 3: Are you sure that you're actually storing the sessions in the database ($CFG->dbsessions is true, and you're using a database which supports session locking)?  Records being present in the database doesn't necessarily mean that the sessions themselves are there - sessions are tracked in the database for other session storage methods too. I ask this as it sounds as though you may have your sessions stored on (local) disk, with the load balancer sending the later request to a different node which doesn't have the session file available.  You may be able to identify this situation by tracking which node serves each request.  If this does turn out to be the problem, switching to either database or memcache/memcached (assuming a single memcached instance is shared by all nodes for this purpose) session handling ought to do the trick; if that's not an option for whatever reason, perhaps you can configure the load balancing to use "sticky" sessions (pinning the user to a single node for the duration of their session) so that all of the requests within a given user's session are served by the same node and thus have the session file available.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Plugin Update Strategy - The Right Way
Post description: Hello, I have written and maintain several plugins (mainly blocks) that we use at my small institution. I'm curious about your strategy to update blocks when you upgrade to a newer Moodle version. Typically, I upgrade the Moodle core on a dev server and see if the blocks throw any errors on update. Then, I tail the logs as I use the block to see if it makes any recommendations on deprecated function calls - for example, the new context_XXX:get_instance(). This is not The Right Way to do this, I know. Is there a simple doc that lists the changes needed to upgrade plugins from one version to the next? If not, what is The Right Way to prepare my plugins for a Moodle version upgrade? Thanks, Marty
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Marty. The release notes come with a list of API changes, eg https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Moodle_2.7_release_notes#Developer_Notes Read the upgrade.txt files within the Moodle codebase for details. Usually this is enough to get plugins up to date. Ideally having proper tests (Behat and phpunit) in your plugin code will reduce your manual testing workload.
Comment 2: Thanks, Chris. That was easy. I looked for this, but obviously incorrectly or not hard enough. Thanks for your help! Marty
Comment 3: Is there a simple doc that lists the changes needed to upgrade plugins from one version to the next? Yes, there is. There are `upgrade.txt` files across the Moodle code base especially for this. You will probably want to check for the main one at `lib/upgrade.txt` for the general core changes and then other ones for plugin type specific changes - such as `blocks/upgrade.txt` . Still, manually checking for your plugins functionality in full developer debugging mode is expected. Having Behat tests written for your plugins helps a lot with this.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Capabilities to Delete Activities (Prevent Deleting of Assignments with Submissions)
Post description: Hi All, We are interested in trying to do something about this: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-45777 But rather than (or as well as) "warning" have the ability to prevent users deleting assignments with submissions all together. There are a couple of ways to do this, the simplest (for us to put in a quick fix) would be to botch the backend code but that wouldn't be good from a users perspective as the initial screens / YUI Modal would imply they could delete. A better approach would be to consider additional capabilities for modules like module:delete-instance-without-data
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I am interested in the "why" for this feature. It seems like a lot of work etc - new APIs to report "hasdata" from modules, changes to the YUI code, caching required in course modinfo, catching and reporting errors, reporting "hasdata" to web services, unit tests. What exactly is the use case when you trust someone to delete modules etc, but not if they have submissions. Have you got learning designers working on courses while students are enrolled ?
Comment 2: Hi Damyon, We don't have "Learning Designers". We have several hundred academics who are self serving in terms of creating / maintaining over 3000 Moodle courses. Courses are continually updated by staff throughout the academic year. As you would expect someone slips up once in a while and that is a big problem if student submissions / grades are involved. What we would like to do is make a distinction between activities with no student activity so that staff retain the ability to create / delete at will when adding new resources but give more protection to resources that students have already contributed to. I know there is a confirm button to click during delete only really guards against stray clicks, it doesn't guard against human error. Clicking that becomes habitual and if you make the mistake of clicking delete in the first place and often you are not going to realise your mistake a second later second later when you are asked to confirm. I know we are not alone in having an issue with this and would like to do something about it but technically I am not sure what the best approach would be.
Comment 3: We get this too. Personally, I'd like to see Moodle introduce more 'soft' deletions (using a flag) for high priority activities Then an admin could reverse the deletion, whilst still ensuring that the person who made the mistake is shamed... I mean aware.
Comment 4: That's an interesting idea and probably easier to implement that trying to build out capabilities / conditional logic in the front end?
Comment 5: Amanda, This seems like the simplest way of implementing this kind of feature, without much of the work that Damyon mentioned. I've had a brief look and Moodle seems to consistently use one function that could be extended to implement this kind of feature (allowing for it to be on or off etc). Then create a 'Reycle Bin' esque page, where people can actually delete items from their courses and that can be capability controlled. Might be worth looking at a cron function too to clear the recycle bins every x days. Obviously all of this idea would need to be configurable, as what we want, would probably be overkill for a small school or business. How far had you got on thinking a bit more into this? This is something that I would be keen to work on, because of the need mentioned by Jez in that 'whoopsie' moments can happen fairly easily.
Comment 6: The "recycle bin" idea is interesting and I think could be quite useful. A
couple of questions around that would be whether you would want to send
everything to the bin or specify specific mod types or conditions (like
has user data). From a users persepective a recycle bin that
caught everything would make sense, and we have accidents with all mod
types not only assignments, it just so happens assignments are the most
critical which is why the original tracker addressed that type
specifically. It would definitely need a clear down process on cron (for us at least), otherwise nothing would ever actually be deleted!
Comment 7: We have this problem too at the Open University. I think what we do is to tell staff never to delete anything. Just hide it from students, then ask an admin to delete it. (I think this is right, but I a bit out of touch with this sort of process.) It might be nice to have moodle/course:manageactivities split so that moodle/course:deleteactivities, but the bit about being able to delete an activity you have just created by mistake, without being able to delete an activity containing a lot of user data, is a good one. The recycle bid idea is probably better.
Comment 8: Hi Tim, I've been burrowing through the code this afternoon to figure out the simplest way of achieving a 'Recycle Bin' . One of the simplest ways that I can think of achieving this (who doesn't prefer simple solutions) is to extend the existing logic for deleting a course module (course/lib.php course_delete_module). My idea is as follows, add a 'deleted' tag to the course_modules table, that will be 0 for not deleted, and when it's set as deleted it would be a timestamp of when. When the delete function is called, it checks to see what this value is, if it's got a timestamp then actually run the delete process. If it hasn't, then set the value to the current timestamp. This then allows for the function that loads course modules for viewing in a course to be changed, to ignore anything with a value set in deleted (We don't want them to appear on a course anymore as they should now be found in the recycle bin). Then we can create a page that loads all the course modules that have a value in a new page called 'Recycle Bin', allowing users to permanently delete this or to restore it. The benefits of this flag and timestamp, is it's simple to restore content back to where it was. And with the timestamp we can empty the recycle bin every x days. There would be backups, and this isn't meant to become a permanent store of information. I'm not sure what others thoughts are on this?
Comment 9: The other approach that might work is to make a separate course section (it could even be section -1, which is then handled as a special case). When an activity is 'deleted', it is instead moved to that section, and automatically hidden from students, etc.
Comment 10: Thats an interesting idea but if you lose the original position / section how would restore work, i.e. which section would you restore to? On a side note I was just lo oking at the screen shot in this post, makes so much sense to do something like this: http://www.moodlenews.com/2013/moodlewish-how-about-a-recycle-bin/
Comment 11: Hi Tim, The reason I suggested adding a flag to the table was so that when you restored an item, it would reappear with all its original settings e.g. Section number. What are your reasons for suggesting moving it to a new course section?
Comment 12: I dont think we would want or need to empty the recycle bin every x days. If we timestamp the point a "deletion" is made and have an admin setting for the retention period cron could just delete anything outside the retention period, everything older than 60 days for example. One thing to consider with that approach is if an admin dropped the setting to zero it would nuke everything which may not be desirable!
Comment 13: From what Mike has said I think the recycle bin idea would actually be easier to implement. If that is done it would be better to catch everything on a course not just assignments as it would make little sense to users if some things were recoverable and not others. In terms of overhead to a given system it would just mean some files / records sticking around for x days longer than they would otherwise, assuming there was a cron process running to clear things down after say 30 days. I don't think this would interfere with course backup / restore as it would just use an additional flag (timestamp) in the mdl_course_modules table which those processes are unaware of. If you could configure retention period in admin individual sites could implement their own policies on clearing down resources after x period, or disable the feature entirely. There would be no impact on the way people use Moodle and I don't think would need any additional capabilities (given there arent any specifically for delete now). All users would see is a "recycle bin" / page that gave them the option to restore / completely delete items up until the time limit set by cron is reached and resources are cleared down automatically. I *think* this could work really nicely.
Comment 14: By coincidence I just received this cry for help from one of our users: " Earlier this week I erroneously deleted a quiz that I
had previously duplicated, this was attempted by approximately 100 of my
students .... It was placed under the currently hidden tab ... I have deleted the wrong version by mistake. "
Comment 15: Hi Jez just to add my thoughts on this the recycle bin is a great idea, as we currently use something similar.  On our moodle we have used groups to create a trash folder where any deleted groups(categories) or courses gets placed.  This means that this data is not then deleted on the site and should someone say they accidently deleted the wrong one at that time this is still in the trashcan and fully recoverable.  However dont let them know this, let them think you can work wonders otherwise they will realise its in trash for 60 days and after 65 days they will come back telling you they have deleted a course awhile but could you retrieve the info from the trash/recycle bin. Scott
Comment 16: Well, let's stop a moment and consider the initial discussion. I interpreted that to mean that Jez H is asking if it is feasible to separate capabilities from the "managefiles" capability. The MDL-45777 certainly suggests this, and yet the conversation seems to have drifted to a recycling option. While recycling is a great idea, or at least as Jez has described it here, it is still the ability to delete that is the core issue here. Oh.. btw , if you delete an instance without deleting data, how do you track the data that is not deleted? If you recreate the instance, do you then connect the data to the new instance or let it remain an orphan?
Comment 17: Hi Colin, What I am trying to do is solve the problem that users can delete important stuff with no way to get it back. We could try and stop them deleting but that will get in the way of users and it looks like it would be difficult to implement. If we can get their stuff back it would probably be more useful and less disruptive, and it looks a lot easier to implement. With this process you dont actually delete when you click delete, it leaves the resource in place with a flag / timestamp which renders it invisible until such time as it is cleaned up (actually deleted) or restored. Users could work exactly as they do now, but if they ever make a mistake they could undo it. I just found these old links which are worth a look, all relate to some kind of recycle bin: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-37139 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=217794 http://www.moodlenews.com/2013/moodlewish-how-about-a-recycle-bin/ I think this would be a better aproach than my initial thought of capabilities which kind of grew out of an assumption they were already there! I still think there should be capabilities for delete as there are for addinstance but there seems to be a significant amount of work to do in the front end to conditionally display the delete options. I think we have a much better shot at getting a recycle feature done.
Comment 18: Hi Jez, A Recycle Bin is actually a good idea, but as Tim points out, there does need to be a lifetime limit for stuff placed in the Bin. I do like your flag idea, but my more immediate interpretation was to divide the "managefiles" capability of editors to add, delete save, edit. I am not sure this can be done easily, it is splitting some hairs rather more finely, nor if it is even desirable to do this in many Moodles. I do know, I created a Role recently where this set of capabilities would save me a serious round of future angst if I could have denied deletion capability. I know it is going to happen, inevitable, the recycle bin provided an alternative, even if not as certain as denying the capability.
Comment 19: I think a recycle bin is a very good idea
Comment 20: See previous thread Safer delete for course modules (aka Recycle Bin) and issue MDL-48012 .
